revision.text:
{{Infobox Politician | image = | name = Clifford Lincoln | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1928|9|1}} | birth_place = [[Mauritius]] | residence = | constituency_MP1 = [[Lac-Saint-Louis]]
[[Lachine—Lac-Saint-Louis]] (1993-1997) | parliament1 = Canadian | term_start1 = October 25, 1993 | term_end1 = June 28, 2004 | predecessor1 = [[Robert Layton]] | successor1 = [[Francis Scarpaleggia]] | office2 = Member of the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] for [[Nelligan (electoral district)|Nelligan]] | term_start2 = April 13, 1981 | term_end2 = September 25, 1989 | predecessor2 = ''Riding Established'' | successor2 = [[Russell Williams (politician)|Russell Williams]] | party = [[Quebec Liberal Party]]
[[Liberal Party of Canada]] | religion = | occupation = Insurance Company Executive }} '''Clifford Albert Lincoln''' (born September 1, 1928) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] politician who served as a member of the [[Quebec National Assembly]], a provincial [[cabinet (government)|cabinet]] minister and a member of the [[House of Commons of Canada]]. Lincoln was born in [[Mauritius]] to Francis Lincoln, a British colonial civil servant, and Régina De Baize. He studied [[insurance]] in Mauritius and in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]]. He emigrated to [[Canada]] in 1958, settling first in [[Vancouver]] and then in [[Montreal]], where he became an insurance company executive. He was first elected to the [[Quebec National Assembly]] in [[Quebec general election, 1981|1981]] as a member of the [[Quebec Liberal Party|Liberal Party]]. When the Liberals formed government in [[Quebec general election, 1985|1985]], Lincoln was appointed Minister of the Environment by Premier [[Robert Bourassa]]. Lincoln and two other [[English-speaking Quebecker|anglophone]] ministers resigned from cabinet in 1989, to protest the Bourassa government's language policy and its adoption of Bill 178,{{cite web |url=http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/10-33.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051119132110/http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/10-33.htm |archivedate=2005-11-19 |df= }} which invoked the [[Section Thirty-three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|notwithstanding clause]] of the [[Canadian Constitution]] to require French to be the dominant language on commercial signs.{{cite web |url=http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051119094915/http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/1.htm |archivedate=2005-11-19 |df= }} He campaigned for the leadership of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]] in [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 1990|1990]]. At the same time, he contested a by-election in the federal electoral district of [[Chambly (electoral district)|Chambly]]. He lost the by-election to [[Phil Edmonston]] of the [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]] and then withdrew from the Liberal leadership contest.http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?Language=E&Search=Det&Include=Y&rid=128 He was elected to Parliament in the [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 federal election]] in the district of [[Lachine—Lac-Saint-Louis]] and was re-elected in [[Lac-Saint-Louis (electoral district)|Lac-Saint-Louis]] in [[Canadian federal election, 1997|1997]] and [[Canadian federal election, 2000|2000]]. He served as [[parliamentary secretary]] to the [[Deputy Prime Minister of Canada|Deputy Prime Minister]] and the [[Minister of the Environment (Canada)|Minister of the Environment]] from 1993 until 1996. He also served as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Canadian Heritage from 1997 until 2004. As such he wrote a report on Canadian broadcasting, ''Our Cultural Sovereignty: The Second Century of Canadian Broadcasting''; its recommendations were largely ignored by the government. Lincoln retired from politics at the [[Canadian general election, 2004|2004 federal election]] and was appointed Chairman of the Panel on Access to Third-language Public Television Services[http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p2/2004/2004-08-25/pdf/g2-13817.pdf Canada Gazette Part II, Vol. 138, No. 17] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306221529/http://www.gazette.gc.ca/archives/p2/2004/2004-08-25/pdf/g2-13817.pdf |date=2012-03-06 }} by the federal government. As of 2007, Lincoln is President of the Board of Directors of the [[English Speaking Catholic Council]] of [[Quebec]].{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=d75dd549-6b6d-4f18-915f-c162ebf4ed05 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103131344/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/story.html?id=d75dd549-6b6d-4f18-915f-c162ebf4ed05 |archivedate=2012-11-03 |df= }} In December 2012, he released ''[http://shorelinepress.ca/?portfolio=toward-new-horizons Toward New Horizons]'', a memoir of his life in politics. == References == ==Sources== *{{QuebecMNAbio|lincoln-clifford-4225}} *{{Canadian Parliament links|ID=7636}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051119132110/http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/10-33.htm Documents on the Controversy Surrounding the Language of Commercial Signs in Quebec (Bill 178) December 1988] Clifford Lincoln's resignation speech, accessed December 26, 2005. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051119094915/http://www2.marianopolis.edu/quebechistory/docs/bill178/1.htm Text of Bill 178], accessed December 26, 2005. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061004063353/http://www.friends.ca/News/Friends_News/archives/articles01030501.asp Remember the Lincoln Report] accessed December 26, 2005. ==Electoral record (incomplete)== {{Canadian federal election, 1993/Lachine—Lac-Saint-Louis}} {{Authority control}} {{Second Bourassa Ministry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lincoln, Clifford}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Canada MPs]] [[Category:Members of the Executive Council of Quebec]] [[Category:Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Quebec]] [[Category:Quebec Liberal Party MNAs]] [[Category:Anglophone Quebec people]] [[Category:People from Plaines Wilhems District]] [[Category:21st-century Canadian politicians]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian politicians]] [[Category:Canadian Catholics]] [[Category:Mauritian people]]

revision.comment: Local description added
revision.text:
{{Short description|15th-century Flemish printer}} [[File:Ovide introduction.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Page from the ''Ovide Moralisé'', with [[woodcut]] and added illumination (Bruges, Public Library, Inc. 3877, f. 294v).]]
'''Colard Mansion''' (or '''Colart''', before 1440 – after May 1484) was a 15th-century [[Flanders|Flemish]] scribe and printer who worked together with [[William Caxton]]. He is known as the first printer of a book with copper [[engraving]]s, and as the printer of the first books in English and French.
==Biography== Colard Mansion was a central figure in the early printing industry in [[Bruges]]. He was active as early as 1454 as a bookseller, and was also active as a [[scribe]], translator and contractor for [[manuscript]]s, which meant entering into contracts with the clients, and organizing and sub-contracting the elements such as scribing, decorating and binding.<ref>Such a contract is described on p. 59 of T Kren & S McKendrick (eds), ''Illuminating the Renaissance: The Triumph of Flemish Manuscript Painting in Europe'', Getty Museum/Royal Academy of Arts, 2003, {{ISBN|1-903973-28-7}}</ref> From 1474 until 1476 he worked together with the early English printer [[William Caxton]], and he continued the company on his own afterwards. Caxton probably learned the art of printing from Mansion,<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=22176 British History Online]</ref> and it was from Mansion's press that the first books printed in English (''[[Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye]]'') and French came.<ref>[http://www.aboutbookbinding.com/story/29.html The Story of Books] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070816234843/http://www.aboutbookbinding.com/story/29.html |date=2007-08-16 }} by Gertrude Burford Rawlings, 1901</ref> He moved to the Burg, the commercial heart of Bruges at the time, in 1478. Mansion suffered heavily under the economic crisis in Bruges in the 1480s, and only one work was printed after the death of [[Mary of Burgundy]] in 1482. Nothing is known with certainty about his life after 1484, although he may have moved to [[Picardy]].
==Work== Mansion sold [[illuminated manuscript]]s to the aristocracy, and luxurious [[incunabulum|incunabula]] to the [[bourgeoisie]], but he was one of the first to also publish smaller and cheaper books of only twenty to thirty pages, mainly in French. Nowadays, 25 editions of incunabula by Mansion alone are known, making him the most prolific of Bruges' early printers. Only two of these are in Latin, all others are in French, many of them first editions. Customers of Mansion include [[Charles de Croÿ, prince of Chimay]], and Marie, the widow of [[Louis de Luxembourg, Count of Saint-Pol]]. Mansion has been called the first printer of luxury books.<ref>[http://www.nieuwsblad.be/Article/Detail.aspx?articleID=g3kb55g8 Drukkunst bezorgde Brugge internationale faam] [[Het Nieuwsblad]], 2004-12-21.</ref>
He collaborated with major manuscript illuminators, such as the [[Master of the Dresden Prayer Book]], who were fast losing work to printing, or copyists of their work. In fact only two of his books are illustrated, the influential ''Ovide Moralisé'' with [[woodcut]]s, and a French translation of [[Boccaccio]]'s ''[[De Casibus Virorum Illustrium]]'', the first book to be illustrated with [[engraving]]s, some of which have been claimed to be the work of the Dresden Prayer Book Master and other identified illuminators in the circle of the [[Master of Anthony of Burgundy]]. As [[Intaglio (sculpture)|intaglio]] prints, the nine engravings had to be printed separately from the relief text and then pasted in, and only three copies are known with the engravings. More copies are known without the engravings, several of which contain illuminations instead. It has been suggested that this was Mansion's original intention (other incunabula left spaces for manual illustration), but that this hybrid product did not attract the wealthy buyers of illuminations, so the engravings were an afterthought, aimed at a less exclusive market.<ref>Copies with engravings are in Amiens, Boston MFA & Getty private Collection, England. T Kren & S McKendrick (eds), ''Illuminating the Renaissance: The Triumph of Flemish Manuscript Painting in Europe'', pp. 271-4, Getty Museum/Royal Academy of Arts, 2003, {{ISBN|1-903973-28-7}}, see also ''An Introduction to a History of Woodcut'', Arthur M. Hind, p. 592, Houghton Mifflin Co. 1935 (in USA), reprinted Dover Publications, 1963 {{ISBN|0-486-20952-0}}</ref> Mansion is also known as the translator of at least five texts from Latin to French, including ''Le dialogue des créatures'', printed by Dutch [[Gerard Leeu]] in 1482.
===Known works=== [[File:Ovide moralisé.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Woodcut from the ''Ovide Moralisé'' illustrating [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]] (Bruges, Public Library, Inc. 3877, f. 9r) ]]
*1467: ''Romuleon'' ([[manuscript]] by [[Benvenuto Rambaldi da Imola]], translated by [[Jean Miélot]], dedicated to [[Philip the Good]]<ref name=Arlima>[http://www.arlima.net/ad/colart_mansion.html Arlima], archives du littérature du moyen-age</ref> *1472 or later: ''Penitence d'Adam'' (''[[Testament of Adam]]'') (manuscript), dedicated to [[Lewis de Bruges]]<ref name=Arlima/> *1474-1475: ''[[Recuyell of the Historyes of Troye]]'', together with William Caxton and [[Johann Veldener]] *1475: ''The Game and Playe of Chesse'', together with Caxton (who translated it from the French version), based on a work by [[Jacobus de Cessolis]] *1476: ''Le Jardin de dévotion'' by [[Petrus de Alliaco]], Mansion's first book as an independent publisher<ref>[http://www.flandrica.be/items/show/895/ Flandrica] Copy of the 1976 (?) edition at Flandrica</ref> *1476: ''De cas de nobles hommes et femmes'' (''[[De Casibus Virorum Illustrium]]'') by [[Giovanni Boccaccio]],<ref>Mitchell, J. Allan. "[http://www.litencyc.com/php/sworks.php?rec=true&UID=909 The Fall of Princes]". The Literary Encyclopedia. First published 07 March 2007; last revised 10 October 2007.</ref> translated into French by [[Laurent Premierfait]], was the first book to be illustrated with [[engraving]]s,<ref>[http://livre.arts-et-metiers.net/exposition/presentation2.html Musée des arts et métiers] exposition on early printed books</ref> probably made by [[Marc le Bongeteur]]. *1476: ''Controversie de Noblesse'' by [[Buonaccorso da Montemagno]] (or [[Surse de Pistoye]]), translated into French by Jean Miélot *1476-1477: an anonymous French [[prediction]] text *1477: ''La consolation de la philosophie'' by [[Boethius]] *1477: ''Estrif de Fortune et de Vertu'' (anonymous)<ref name=Arlima/> *1477: ''Traité de l’espere'', French translation of the ''Tractatus de Origine, Natura, Jure et Mutationibus Monetarum'' by [[Nicole Oresme]] in 26 chapters<ref>[http://phare.univ-paris1.fr/textes/Oresme/notice.html André Lapidus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116042902/http://phare.univ-paris1.fr/textes/Oresme/notice.html |date=2006-11-16 }} 1998</ref> *1479: ''[[Quadrilogue-invectif|Le quadriloque invectif]]'' by [[Alain Chartier]] *1479: ''La somme rurale'' by [[Jean Boutillier]] *1479: ''Opera : De caelesti hyerarchia. De ecclesiastica hyerarchia. De divinis nominibus. De mystica theologia. Epistolae'', a complete edition in Latin of the works of [[Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite]], translated by [[St. Ambrose Traversari|Ambrosio Traversari]] *1480: ''Art de bien mourir'' (anonymous) *1480?: [[Guillaume Caoursin]], ''Rhodiae Obsidionis descriptio''<ref name=Kelly>{{cite book|last=Kelly|first=William A.|title=Low Countries imprints in Scottish research libraries|year=2007|publisher=Waxmann Verlag|isbn=978-3-8309-1866-0|pages=157|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iJTN1_qLZtcC&pg=PA25&dq=incunabula&hl=en&ei=R2fWTc-BJYiF-waRkszEBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=incunabula&f=false|accessdate=20 May 2011}}</ref> *before June 1481: ''Valere Maxime'' (life of [[Saint Hubert]]), dedicated to [[Philippe de Hornes]]<ref name=Arlima/> *1482: ''Dyalogue des creatures'', translated by Mansion from the Latin ''Dialogus creaturarum''<ref name=Arlima/> *1484: ''Ovide moralisé'', first edition of [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]'', illustrated with woodcuts, rearranged and partly rewritten by Mansion himself, published in May 1484.<ref>[http://www.historischebronnenbrugge.be/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=68 Historische Bronnen Brugge]</ref> It is his last known work, and it has been speculated that the expensive book bankrupted the company. This book was reprinted as the ''Bible des poëtes'' (Poets' Bible) at least four times in Paris between 1493 and 1531. Afterwards, a purer version (with all allegorical additions by Mansion removed, but keeping his translations) under the title ''Grand Olympe des histoires poëtiques du Prince de poësie Ovide Naso en sa Metamorphose'' was published repeatedly between 1532 and 1570. *Unknown date: **the ''[[Distichs of Cato]]'' **''Les Evangiles des quenouilles'' (anonymous, circa 1480) **''La doctrine de bien vivre en ce monde'' (also called ''Donat espirituel'') by [[Jean Gerson]] **''La Danse des aveugles'' by [[Pierre Michault]], secretary of [[Charles the Bold]] **''Invectives contre la secte de Vauderie'' **''Adevineaux amoureux'' (anonymous).<ref name=Arlima/>
Incunabula by Mansion are scattered throughout collections mainly in Western Europe. The largest such collection is in Paris, and the 16 copies of 10 different titles in the Public Library of Bruges form the second biggest collection.<ref>[http://www.historischebronnenbrugge.be/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=38&Itemid=78 Mansion collection of the Bruges library (Openbare Bibliotheek Brugge)]</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *T Kren & S McKendrick (eds), ''Illuminating the Renaissance: The Triumph of Flemish Manuscript Painting in Europe'', Getty Museum/Royal Academy of Arts, 2003, {{ISBN|1-903973-28-7}} *[http://www.historischebronnenbrugge.be/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=36&Itemid=76 Biography at Historische Bronnen Brugge] Last accessed at September 27, 2007 *[http://www.kb.nl/galerie/100hoogtepunten/024-en.html Short biography in English at the Dutch Royal Library] Last accessed at September 27, 2007 *{{cite book|last=Carton|first=Charles Louis|title=Colard Mansion et les imprimeurs brugeois du 15me siècle|year=1848|publisher=Vande Casteele-Werbroeck|pages=44|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ksxbAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA5&dq=%22colard+mansion%22&hl=en&ei=o2jWTbbOOY6c-wa4mfnkBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=20 May 2011|language=French}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mansion, Colard}} [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:15th-century deaths]] [[Category:Printers of incunabula]] [[Category:French calligraphers]] [[Category:Medieval European scribes]] [[Category:Flemish people]] [[Category:Belgian printers]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:University of Western Sydney alumni]] to [[Category:Western Sydney University alumni]] per [[WP:CFDS]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} '''Deng Thiak Adut''' is a [[defence lawyer]] and refugee advocate in [[Western Sydney]], [[Australia]], and a former [[Military use of children|child soldier]] from [[South Sudan]]. His story is told in a popular short video by [[Western Sydney University]], where he earned his law degree. He was named the 2017 New South Wales Australian of the Year.
== Early life == A member of the [[Dinka people]], Adut was born near Malek, a small fishing village in South Sudan near [[White Nile River]].<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|4}}<ref name=SMHT/><ref name=DeadofNight/> One of eight children,<ref name=SMHT/> he had a happy early childhood spent with his family at their banana farm.<ref name=SBS/><ref name=SMH/>
In 1987 at the age of 6 or 7 years,{{refn|group=note|6 according to various news sources<ref name=SMHT/><ref name=UWS/> or 7 according to Adut's autobiography<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|12}}}} Adut was taken from his mother and marched for 33 days to [[Ethiopia]] along with 30 other child conscripts.<ref name=DeadofNight/> During the march, some boys died of starvation or thirst, others were shot by bandits, and others attacked by wild animals.<ref name=DeadofNight/> The boys were forced to fight for the [[Sudan People's Liberation Army]] in the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]].<ref name=SMHT/><ref name=UWS/> They were [[Mind control|brainwashed]] and given daily doses of [[khat]], a herbal [[stimulant]] drug popular in East Africa.<ref name=DeadofNight/> Adut was taught to use an [[AK-47]] assault rifle and other weapons. He witnessed many atrocities, including people dying from dehydration and a [[grenade]] explosion and children committing suicide.<ref name=Sales/><ref name=SBS/><ref name=SMHT/> At 12 years of age he was shot in the testicles and back and almost bled to death.<ref name=Sales/><ref name=SBS/><ref name=DeadofNight/>
In 1995, Adut's older half-brother, John Mac, smuggled Adut out of Sudan at night in a truck under sacks of corn.<ref name=SBS/><ref name=Austn/><ref name=DeadofNight/> Adut spent 18 months in a refugee camp in [[Kenya]].<ref name=Austn/> The United Nations granted both brothers [[refugee]] status,<ref name=SBS/> and in 1998 when Adut was 14, Australia granted both boys a [[Travel visa|visa]].<ref name=Austn/>
== In Australia == Adut reached Australia in 1998 at age 14 due to sponsorship by Christian aid workers Bob and Christine Harrison.<ref name=SBS/><ref name=DeadofNight/> He was part of the third family to come to Australia as Sudanese refugees.<ref name=Neptune/> He had little education and did not know English,<ref name=Teleg/> and initially felt isolated as a member of the only black family in [[Blacktown]], [[Sydney]].<ref name=SBS/> At 15 Adut taught himself English, in part by using ''[[The Wiggles]]'' children's television program and the Bible as examples, though Adut is an avowed atheist.<ref name=SBS/><ref name=Neptune/><ref name=DeadofNight/> He worked myriad part-time jobs including making concrete, carpet, windows and doors, catching chickens, working in a meat factory, working in a petrol station, and mowing lawns.<ref name=Sales/><ref name=SMH/><ref name=SMHT/> He became an Australian citizen in 2001.<ref name=DeadofNight/>
In 2001, Adut completed a [[TAFE]] course equivalent to a high school certificate.<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|74}} Subsequently he completed an Advanced Diploma in Accounting at TAFE.<ref name=UWS/> He rejected an offer to study at [[Macquarie University]] following [[Drew Fraser#Non-white immigration and multiculturalism|racist remarks]] by Macquarie law professor [[Drew Fraser]],<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|82}} instead accepting admission to [[Western Sydney University]] on a scholarship. The first in his family to earn a university degree, Adut graduated with a [[Bachelor of Laws]],<ref name=SBS/> and worked for Grace Legal and then LN Legal.<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|87,91}} Along with solicitor Joseph Correy, Adut co-founded AC Law Group and is still a partner,<ref name=SMH/><ref name=SBS/> supporting youths of Western Sydney's Sudanese community as a [[defence lawyer]].<ref name=Teleg/><ref name=AusDay/> He performs much of his work ''[[pro bono]]''.<ref name=SMH/><ref name=Songs/>{{rp|89}}<ref name=DeadofNight/>
Adut founded the John Mac Foundation in honour of his half-brother, John Mac Acuek, who helped Adut escape South Sudan and died in 2014 while leading an effort to rescue South Sudanese civilians from ongoing conflict.<ref name=JohnMac/> The Foundation provides higher education scholarships to students from refugee backgrounds.<ref name=SMH/> Adut sponsors "Savannah Pride", a Blacktown basketball team.<ref name=Austn/>
In 2017 Adut condemned the [[Executive Order 13769|ban on immigration to the United States]] ordered by US President Donald Trump. He said, "The culture of punishing the innocent and weak countries has got to stop. It's not stopping wars; it's creating them. It's creating economic deprivation for the local people; the victims are the poor, the ones that have no skills, the refugees."<ref name=9News/>
Adut completed a [[Master of Laws]] in Criminal Prosecution at [[Wollongong University]]<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|137}} and has a scholarship to return to Western Sydney University for a second Master of Laws in International Governance.<ref name=DeadofNight/> He ultimately aims to return to South Sudan to prosecute those responsible for the conscription of child soldiers.<ref name=LawSoc/>
== Recognition ==
In 2015 Western Sydney University produced a short video about Adut's life up to his 2012 reunion with his mother, who was still living in Adut's childhood home in South Sudan.<ref name=UWS/><ref name=Sales/> Viewed over 2 million times on YouTube,<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|140}} Adut says it "has helped others understand the horrors that see people seek asylum in safer countries", and helped him promote the importance of education.<ref name=Songs/>{{rp|140}}
On 27 October 2016 Adut was awarded the 2016 [[NSW Law Society|Law Society of New South Wales]] President's Medal. Society president Gary Ulman said the award is "testament to [Adut's] personal and professional achievements over a number of years, and to his outstanding contribution to the community of Western Sydney."<ref name=LawSoc/>
Also in 2016 Adut was named New South Wales Australian of the Year for 2017. The announcement was made by the state Premier [[Mike Baird]], who said Adut "has channelled his success into helping hundreds of people in the state's Sudanese community navigate their way through the Australian legal system."<ref name=SMH/>
An acrylic and oil on linen portrait of Adut titled ''Deng'' by artist Nick Stathopoulos won the People's Choice Award in the 2016 Archibald Prize at the [[Art Gallery of New South Wales]].<ref name=Archibald/>
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title=Songs of a War Boy | first=Deng | last=Adut | publisher=Hachette Australia | location=Sydney, N.S.W | year=2016 | isbn=0-7336-3651-9 }}
==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}}
==References == {{Reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name=9News>{{cite news |url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2017/01/30/17/19/deng-adut-calls-president-trumps-immigration-ban-hypocritical |title=NSW Australian of the Year Deng Adut calls President Trump’s immigration ban 'hypocritical' |date=30 January 2017 |publisher=''Nine News'' |accessdate=2017-02-03 }}</ref>
<ref name=Archibald>{{cite web |url=https://www.artgallery.nsw.gov.au/prizes/archibald/2016/29726/ |title=Nick Stathopoulos: Deng – Archibald Prize 2016 |publisher=Art Gallery of New South Wales |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=AusDay>{{cite web |url=https://www.australiaday.com.au/media-and-resources/latest-news/2016/01/21/defense-lawyer-and-refugee-advocate-deng-thiak-adut-to-deliver-2016-australia-day-address/ |title=Defense Lawyer and Refugee Advocate Deng Thiak Adut to Deliver 2016 Australia Day Address |date=21 January 2017 |accessdate=2017-02-03 |publisher=Australia Day Council of NSW }} Press release.</ref>
<ref name=Austn>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/australia-day-honours/deng-aduts-path-from-child-soldier-to-model-citizen/news-story/0c4176ba8f2e4c0b1f0f5971232771d8 |url-access=subscription |title=Deng Adut’s path from child soldier to model citizen |first=Simon |last=King |publisher=''The Australian'' |date=25 January 2017 |accessdate=2017-01-26 }}</ref>
<ref name=DeadofNight>{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/weekend-australian-magazine/child-soldier-turned-lawyer-deng-adut-transforms-trauma-into-hope/news-story/f6ffedfd0bb891a1507bbf81d4fab208 |publisher=''The Australian'' |title=In the dead of night – Child soldier turned lawyer Deng Adut transforms trauma into hope |date=22 October 2016 |first=Megan |last=Lehmann |accessdate=2017-02-07 }}</ref>
<ref name=JohnMac>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/obituaries/south-sudan-refugee-john-mac-acuik-killed-on-mercy-mission-in-homeland-20140122-318ul.html |title=South Sudan refugee John Mac Acuik killed on mercy mission in homeland |first=Hugh |last=Riminton |publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald'' |date=23 January 2014 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=LawSoc>{{cite web |url=https://www.lawsociety.com.au/about/news/1207146 |title=Former child soldier wins NSW Law Society President’s Medal |publisher=The Law Society of New South Wales |date=28 October 2016 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=Neptune>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/deng-thiak-adut-australia-was-a-place-that-was-as-strange-to-me-as-neptune-may-be-to-you-20161109-gslcy4.html |title=Deng Thiak Adut: Australia was 'a place that was as strange to me as Neptune may be to you' |publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald''|date=13 November 2016 |first=Deng |last=Adut |accessdate=2017-02-03 }} Extract from ''Songs of a War Boy''.</ref>
<ref name=Sales>{{cite news |title=Deng Adut on being a child soldier, moving to Australia and dealing with racism |url=http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2016/s4563224.htm |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work=[[7.30]] |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=SBS>{{cite news |title=First day: The former child soldier practising law in Sydney's west |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2016/01/20/first-day-former-child-soldier-practicing-law-sydneys-west |publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] |work=SBS News |first=Rachael |last=Hocking |date=22 January 2016 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=SMH>{{cite news |title=Deng Adut named NSW Australian of the Year |url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/deng-adut-named-nsw-australian-of-the-year-20161106-gsjfvz.html |first=Michaela |last=Whitbourn |publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald'' |date=7 November 2016 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=SMHT>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/transcript-deng-thiak-aduts-australia-day-speech-20160121-gmau63.html |title=Transcript: Deng Thiak Adut's Australia Day speech |date=21 January 2017 |publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald'' |accessdate=2017-01-27 }}</ref>
<ref name=Songs>{{cite book | last=Adut | first=Deng | title=Songs of a War Boy | publisher=Hachette Australia | location=Sydney, N.S.W | year=2016 | isbn=0-7336-3651-9 }}</ref>
<ref name=Teleg>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/lifestyle/aotd/child-soldier-and-refugee-turned-lawyer-deng-adut-is-a-nominee-for-australian-of-the-year/news-story/067203fee3abe7360767855a25377393 |publisher=''The Daily Telegraph'' |title=Child soldier and refugee turned lawyer Deng Adut is a nominee for Australian of the Year |date=23 January 2017 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
<ref name=UWS>{{cite web |url=https://www.westernsydney.edu.au/unlimited/stories_of_unlimited#stories-927799 |title=Stories of Unlimited – Deng Thiak Aduk, Defence Lawyer |publisher=[[Western Sydney University]] |accessdate=2017-01-26}}</ref>
}}
==External links== * [http://dengadut.com/ Personal website] * [http://aclawgroup.com.au/ AC Law Group] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170202060750/https://johnmacfoundation.org/ John Mac Foundation]

revision.comment: /* Aftermath */
revision.text:
{{use Australian English|date=December 2016}} {{use DMY dates|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Cheryl Grimmer | image = | birth_name = Cheryl Gene Grimmer | birth_date = 1966 | birth_place = [[Knowle, Bristol|Knowle]], [[Bristol]], [[England]] | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|1970|1|12|1967|1|4}} | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|1970|1|12}} | known_for = [[Kidnapping]] victim | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | occupation = | parents = Carole Grimmer (mother)
John Grimmer (father) }} '''Cheryl Grimmer''' (born 1966) was a three-year-old toddler who went missing on 12 January 1970 from a [[Wollongong]] beach, in [[Illawarra]], [[New South Wales]], Australia. She had been in the shower block at the beach when witnesses claim a man took her and ran off. Grimmer's disappearance has been without explanation for over 45 years. A suspect was arrested and charged in March 2017. ==Life== The family emigrated from [[Knowle, Bristol|Knowle]], a suburb of [[Bristol]], England to Australia in 1969{{cite news|last1=Grimshaw|first1=Emma|title=Killer of three-year-old Bristol girl snatched from an Australian beach could soon be discovered|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/murderer-of-three-year-old-bristol-girl-snatched-from-an-australian-beach-could-soon-be-discovered/story-29966436-detail/story.html|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=Bristol Post|date=7 December 2016}} when Cheryl was two years old and they were living in a hostel near to the beach where she disappeared.{{cite news|last1=Morri|first1=Mark|title=Cheryl Grimmer disappearance: Cops close in on little girl’s killer 47 years later|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/cheryl-grimmer-disapearance-cops-close-in-on-little-girls-killer-47-years-later/news-story/79060c709bd34593d7c1f0fdd4473459|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=4 December 2016}} The family was mother Carole (26), father John (24) and sons Ricki (7), Stephen (5) and Paul (4). Cheryl was the Grimmers' only daughter.{{cite web|title=The disappearance of Cheryl Grimmer|url=https://forgottenillawarra.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/the-disappearance-of-cheryl-grimmer/|website=forgottenillawarra.wordpress.com|publisher=forgotten illawarra|accessdate=8 December 2016|date=28 January 2014}} ==Disappearance== On the morning of 12 January 1970, the Grimmer family went to the beach at Fairy Meadow in Illawarra except for John Grimmer who was away working as a sapper for the Australian Army.{{cite news|last1=Mardon|first1=Cydonee|title=Heartache endures for lost little girl Cheryl Grimmer|url=http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/2442566/heartache-endures-for-lost-little-girl-cheryl-grimmer-photos-video/|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=Illawarra Mercury|date=25 July 2014}} When the weather turned at 1:30 pm, Carole Grimmer decided it was time to go home. The children all went to the shower block together whilst Carole Grimmer packed up their belongings. Ricki went back to Carole Grimmer ten minutes later saying that Cheryl was refusing to come out of the shower block.{{cite news|last1=Buckingham-Jones|first1=Sam|title=Cheryl Grimmer: breakthrough in cold case abduction|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/cheryl-grimmer-breakthrough-in-cold-case-abduction/news-story/dc25ad0c6291ed89bae150bbd8d6be9e|accessdate=8 December 2016|work=The Australian|date=5 December 2016}} She followed Ricki back to the shower block moments later only to find that Cheryl had disappeared. There has been no trace of her since. ==Theories== At the time, witnesses claimed that a man was seen holding Cheryl up to drink from a water fountain and then ran off with her wrapped up in a towel. She was also spotted being driven off in a white car. New South Wales Police Minister Michael Gallagher said that it is entirely possible that both Cheryl and her kidnapper were dead but that someone may know the truth. He also alluded to the possibility of someone being alive today suspecting that they may be Cheryl. One reason for this is that Cheryl had a medical condition that made her belly button protrude outwards by {{convert|10|mm}} and this would be easily identifiable if that person were alive today or if they had surgery to correct this. In 2012 a woman thought that she might be Cheryl. She submitted a DNA swab taken from her inside cheek, but this proved to not be a match for Cheryl Grimmer's DNA. ==Investigation== Her disappearance sparked a massive manhunt and three days later, police received a note demanding $10,000 and saying that the child was unharmed. The police staged a drop for the money in [[Bulli, New South Wales|Bulli]], but the kidnapper never showed despite police earnestly believing the note was credible. The police disguised themselves as council workers for the ransom drop, but they fear this led to the kidnapper being spooked and that the large police operation may have also deterred the kidnapper from coming forward to claim their ransom.{{cite news|title=Reward for clues in 1970 child kidnap|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/reward-for-clues-in-1970-child-kidnap/news-story/656c99171ddd6367164cf8bb64e3a41b|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=The Australian|date=10 September 2012}} The case became famous in Australia and the family relocated back to England for ten years afterwards to escape the notoriety.{{cite news|last1=Hoctor|first1=Michelle|title=41 years on, family hunts for clues on Cheryl Grimmer disappearance|url=http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/635704/41-years-on-family-hunts-for-clues-on-cheryl-grimmer-disappearance/|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=Illawarra Mercury|date=4 May 2011}} A local man confessed to killing Cheryl, but police investigations revealed that his confession was false.{{cite web|last1=Hicks|first1=Stacey|title=The day my baby sister disappeared|url=http://justineford.net/wp-content/uploads/SNATCHED.pdf|website=justineford.net|accessdate=12 December 2016|format=PDF}} ==Aftermath== In May 2011, a coroner ruled that Cheryl had died sometime after going missing due to an undetermined cause, but Carole Grimmer stated that she believed her daughter was still alive. Both Carole and John Grimmer have since died without knowing what happened to Cheryl.{{cite news|title=Breakthrough in 46-year mystery of missing toddler|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-38219550|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=BBC News|date=6 December 2016}} Despite the coroner's ruling, police posted a $100,000 reward for information regarding Cheryl's disappearance. In 2016, a review of the evidence was carried out and all of the evidence and witness statements were computerised for the first time. The review threw up many leads and information that was not pursued thoroughly enough in 1970. Wollongong detectives and the Homicide Squad's Unsolved Homicide Team combined efforts into a new task force called 'Strike Force Wessell'.{{cite news|last1=Thompson|first1=Angela|title=Illawarra toddler Cheryl Grimmer's kidnapper and suspected killer still alive: police|url=http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/4334478/cold-case-breakthrough-cheryls-killer-still-alive-police-say/|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=Illawarra Mercury|date=5 December 2016}} Police announced in December 2016 that they had a credible lead on a man who was seen carrying a fair-haired child at the time of Cheryl's disappearance from the beach. Police said that he was a teenager at the time, so would be in his 60s now, and appealed for him to come forward.{{cite news|title=Cheryl Grimmer case: police reportedly identify suspect 50 years after toddler's abduction|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/dec/05/cheryl-grimmer-case-police-reportedly-identify-suspect-50-years-after-toddlers-abduction|accessdate=8 December 2016|work=The Guardian|date=4 December 2016}} On 23 March 2017, it was announced that a man had been arrested and charged with Grimmer's abduction and murder. Police stated that it is unlikely that Cheryl's body will ever be found as there has been substantial development of the once-rural area in the 47 years since the abduction.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2016/s4641198.htm|title=Man arrested 47 years after disappearance of 3-year-old Cheryl Grimmer|work=ABC News Sydney|date=23 March 2017|access-date=24 March 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Mitchell|first1=Georgina|title=Breakthrough in toddler Cheryl Grimmer 1970 cold case murder as man arrested|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/cheryl-grimmer-man-arrested-over-1970-cold-case-murder-of-illawarra-toddler-20170322-gv4aij.html|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=23 March 2017|date=23 March 2017}} In April 2017, NSW police stated that they were trying to trace a family who gave a witness statement on the day of the abduction. The family moved soon after to [[Papua New Guinea]] and then back to their native [[Nottinghamshire]] in England.{{cite news|title=Cheryl Grimmer: UK family sought over 1970 toddler death|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-nottinghamshire-39586512|accessdate=13 April 2017|work=BBC News|date=13 April 2017}} Interpol helped to trace the witness, now 80-years old, whose testimony is expected to be crucial in the upcoming court case.{{cite news|last1=Lagan|first1=Bernard|title=British man key to solving 47-year-old Australian abduction|work=The Times|issue=72234|date=27 May 2017|page=23|issn=0140-0460}} In May 2017, it was revealed that the suspect who was arrested in March 2017 had confessed to Cheryl's abduction and murder back in 1970. However, police at the time did not believe him.{{cite news|title=Cheryl Grimmer: Accused man gave evidence in 1971, court hears|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-australia-40024825|accessdate=25 May 2017|work=BBC News|date=25 May 2017}} The accused is a 63-year-old man who was born in Britain and has been in Australia since the late 1960s. He has not been named, as he was 16-years-old at the time of the alleged offence and therefore a minor.{{cite news|last1=Lagan|first1=Bernard|title=Toddler's 'killer' confessed to police five decades ago|work=The Times|issue=72233|date=26 May 2017|page=15|issn=0140-0460}} ==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grimmer, Cheryl}} [[Category:1970 crimes in Australia]] [[Category:1970s missing person cases]] [[Category:Child abduction in Australia]] [[Category:Kidnapped Australian children]] [[Category:Missing people]] [[Category:Missing person cases in Australia]] [[Category:Missing Australian children]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}}
'''Édgar Chamorro Coronel''' (born 23 July 1931) is an ousted leader of the [[Nicaragua]]n rebel [[Contras]] who later became a critic of the rebels and their [[Central Intelligence Agency]] sponsors, even cooperating with the Sandinista government in their World Court case, ''[[Nicaragua v. United States]]''. He is a member of the prominent [[Chamorro (family)|Chamorro family]] that provided five of Nicaragua's past presidents.<ref>http://www.envio.org.ni/articulo/470</ref>
==Early life== Edgar Chamorro is the son of Julio Chamorro Benard and wife Dolores "Lola" Coronel Urtecho, paternal grandson of Filadelfo Chamorro Bolaños and wife Bertha Benard Vivas and great-grandson of [[Pedro Joaquín Chamorro Alfaro|Pedro Joaquín Chamorro y Alfaro]], 39th President of Nicaragua, and wife María de la Luz Bolaños Bendaña. He has six brothers and four sisters,<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Fallece doña Lola Coronel de Chamorro |url=http://www.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2006/06/17/nacionales/22030 |format= |work= |publisher=[[El Nuevo Diario]] |location=Managua, Nicaragua |id= |page= |date=17 June 2006 |accessdate=25 May 2008 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120728230924/http://www.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2006/06/17/nacionales/22030 |archivedate=28 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and is the nephew of intellectual [[José Coronel Urtecho]]. In 1950, 19-year-old Chamorro began studying for the [[Jesuit]] priesthood, earning degrees from Ecuador's [[Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador|Catholic University]], [[Saint Louis University]], and [[Marquette University]]. Chamorro joined the faculty of the Jesuit-run [[University of Central America (Managua)|University of Central America]], before leaving the priesthood in 1969. He got another degree from [[Harvard University]] in 1972 and founded a public relations and marketing firm, Creative Publicity, in [[Managua]]. In 1977, [[Anastasio Somoza Debayle]] appointed him to a figurehead post as a special ambassador to the [[United Nations General Assembly]] for a year.
==Activities during Nicaraguan civil war== During the [[Sandinista]] Revolution, Chamorro sympathized with the rebels, at one point hiding [[Sergio Ramírez]] from the [[National Guard (Nicaragua)|National Guard]]. But as the civil war's climax brought fierce fighting to the capital itself, fears for his family's safety led him to leave for [[Miami, Florida]] on June 17, 1979. Somoza fell a month later, but after visiting Nicaragua in September, Chamorro decided to remain in Miami.
By late 1979, Chamorro had become involved in the anti-Sandinista activities of the Miami exile community. He joined the [[Nicaraguan Democratic Union]] (UDN), formed the next year by [[José Francisco Cardenal]], which merged into the [[Nicaraguan Democratic Force]] (FDN) in August 1981. He served on the FDN's political executive committee, which decided to replace Cardenal with a new political directorate. Chamorro was tapped to be a member of the directorate, unveiled at a December 8, 1982 press conference. With his public relations experience, he took on a spokesman role for the FDN, and based himself in [[Tegucigalpa]], Honduras to liaison with journalists covering the war. Chamorro claimed that the [[CIA]] prepped him before press conferences and told him to deny that the group had received any funding from the US government.<ref>{{cite book|last=Webb|first=Gary|year=1999|pp=74|title=[[Dark Alliance]]|publisher=[[Seven Stories Press]]|isbn=978-1-888363-93-7|ref=harv}}</ref>
Chamorro was miffed when the FDN directorate, at the CIA's prompting, appointed [[Adolfo Calero]] as its president in October 1983. His not-so-private grumblings that his Chamorro lineage was more illustrious than Calero's did not help their deteriorating relations.<ref>Glenn Garvin, ''Everybody Had His Own Gringo: The CIA and the Contras'', Brassey's (US), 1992, p. 132, {{ISBN|0-08-040562-2}}; Cruz, Arturo Jr., ''Memoirs of a Counter-Revolutionary: Life With the Contras, the Sandinistas, and the CIA'', Doubleday, 1989, p. 176, {{ISBN|0-385-24879-2}}.</ref> Chamorro was forced out in November 1984, in the fallout from the furor over the CIA's ''[[Psychological Operations in Guerrilla Warfare]]'', labeled by the press a "murder manual." He turned against the rebel movement, even submitting an affidavit for the Sandinista government before the [[International Court of Justice]] in ''[[Nicaragua v. United States]]''.
==After the war== Chamorro is author of ''Packaging the Contras: A Case of C.I.A. Disinformation'' (1987). He has served as a teacher of [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Latin language|Latin]] and Latin American Studies at [[Bard College at Simon's Rock]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.simons-rock.edu/academics/faculty/chamorro.html |title=Simon's Rock College: Edgar Chamorro |publisher=Bard College at Simon's Rock, where he was one of the most beloved faculty members by all his students, and even ones who never took a class from him |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021002012924/http://www.simons-rock.edu/academics/faculty/chamorro.html |archivedate=2 October 2002 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> since 1990 (full-time to 2003),<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=BCC to offer Latin American History Course this fall |url=http://www.iberkshires.com/story.php?story_id=17869 |format= |work=iBerkshires.com |publisher=Boxcar Media LLC |location=North Adams, MA |page=29 |date=July 2005 |accessdate=25 May 2008}}</ref> and the [[John Dewey Academy]] in [[Great Barrington, Massachusetts]] since 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jda.org/faculty.html |title=The John Dewey Academy: Faculty |accessdate=24 May 2008 |date=29 July 2007 |publisher=The John Dewey Academy}}</ref>
==References==
:{{cite news |first=Edgar |last=Chamorro |authorlink= |author= |author2=Jefferson Morley |title=Confessions of a 'Contra' |publisher=[[The New Republic]] |location= |pages=18–23 |date=5 August 1985}} {{reflist}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chamorro, Edgar}} [[Category:Contras]] [[Category:Nicaraguan diplomats]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Former Jesuits]] [[Category:Bard College at Simon's Rock faculty]] [[Category:Chamorro family|Edgar Chamorro]] [[Category:Permanent Representatives of Nicaragua to the United Nations]] [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People of the Nicaraguan Revolution]]

revision.text:
'''Francita Alavez''' (c. 1816 – c. 1906) was known as the "Angel of Goliad," for saving the lives of Texas prisoners of war in the "Goliad Massacre" and at Copano and Victoria, Texas, by interceding on their behalf and persuading the help of Mexican officials.
==Early life== Francita's definite date and town of birth are not known. Even her real name has been referred to differently at times, such as '''Panchita''', '''Francisca''', '''Pancheta''', or '''Francita''', and her surname as '''Alevesco''', '''Alvárez''', or '''Alavez'''.
==Texas revolution== During the [[Texas Revolution]], she did travel to Texas in 1836, as a companion of Captain Telesforo Alavez, who had sailed to Texas from [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros]], Mexico to El Cópano port at Copano Bay, Texas.
==An Angel of mercy== {{further|Goliad Campaign}} At [[Copano, Texas|El Cópano]], she combined her compassion for humanity with her strong willed personality to influence important Mexican officials to treat the Texian prisoners humanely. When 80 soldiers of Major William Parsons Miller and the Nashville Battalion were captured by Urrea's soldiers, she influenced the Mexican soldiers to untie the men's hands and to give them something to eat.<ref>{{cite web |first=George O. |last=Coalson |title=Alavez, Francita |work=Handbook of Texas Online |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fal53 |accessdate=June 19, 2011 |publisher=Texas State Historical Association}}</ref>
In La Bahia [[Goliad, Texas|(Goliad)]], due to the intervention of this [[Angel of Goliad]] and the courageous effort of Colonel Francisco Garay, 20 more men were held and spared as doctors, interpreters, or workers.<ref name=hardin237>Hardin (1994), pg. 237</ref> Francita entered the presidio the night before the massacre, bringing several men out with her and hiding them until after the [[Goliad Massacre]]. She also made sure the 80 men from Miller's Natchez group were not executed.
In [[Victoria, Texas|Victoria]], where her husband was left in charge, she saw to it that the 26 [[Texian]] boat builders and workers there would be released and not executed.<ref>{{cite web |first=Craig H. |last=Roell |title=Georgia Battalion |work=Handbook of Texas Online |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qjg01 |accessdate=June 20, 2011 |publisher=Texas State Historical Association}}</ref>
==Aftermath== After the defeat of Santa Anna, Francita returned with Captain Alavez to [[Matamoros, Tamaulipas|Matamoros]]. At the prison in Matamoros, she continued to support the Texians imprisoned there. When Captain Alavez left for Mexico City, Francita went with him. But their relationship soon ended. She then left Mexico City and returned to Matamoros. While broke and down on her luck, she was befriended by Texians who knew of her humanitarian acts. The 1936 memoirs of Elena O'Shea, a King Ranch schoolteacher, claim that Francita Alavez traveled back to Texas with her new friends, where she was employed to work on the ranch.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=TAMU |title=Goliad Angel |url=http://www.tamu.edu/faculty/ccbn/dewitt/goliadangel.htm |work=Sons of DeWitt Colony Texas |first=Wallace L. |last=McKeehan}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Citations== *{{cite book |last=Hardin |first=Stephen L. |authorlink=Stephen L. Hardin |year=1994 |title=Texian Iliad – A Military History of the Texas Revolution |location=Austin, TX |publisher=University of Texas Press |isbn=0-292-73086-1|oclc=29704011}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/qeg02 |title=Goliad Massacre |last1=Davenport |first1=Harbert |last2=Roell |first2=Craig H. |last-author-amp=yes |date= |work= |publisher=Handbook of Texas Online |accessdate=19 June 2011}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alavez, Francita}} [[Category:People of the Texas Revolution]] [[Category:Pre-statehood history of Texas]]

{{Infobox person | name = Frank Potenza | image = | caption = | other_names = Uncle Frank | birth_name = Francis Potenza | birth_date = {{Birth date|1933|11|11|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|8|23|1933|11|11|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | spouse = | known_for = ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' | signature = }}
'''Francis "Frank" Potenza''' (November 11, 1933 – August 23, 2011) was an American [[police officer]] for the [[New York City Police Department]] and [[security guard]]. He later became a [[television actor]] for the [[Late-night talk show|late night show]], ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]''. He appeared as [[Jimmy Kimmel]]'s "Uncle Frank" on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] show as a regular from 2003 until his death in 2011.<ref name=latimes>{{cite news|title=Passings: Frank Potenza, John Howard Davies, Jack Layton|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/24/local/la-me-passings-20110824 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2011-08-24|accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref name=nydailynews>{{cite news|first=Nancy|last=Dillon|title=Frank Potenza, 'Uncle Frank' on nephew Jimmy Kimmel's late-night show, dead at 77|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2011-08-23/entertainment/29939634_1_abc-s-jimmy-kimmel-live-frank-sinatra-nephew|work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=2011-08-23|accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref><ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|first=Bill|last=Carter|title=Frank Potenza, Foil for Kimmel, Is Dead at 77|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/26/arts/television/frank-potenza-foil-for-nephew-jimmy-kimmel-dies-at-77.html|work=[[New York Times]]|date=2011-08-26|accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref>
==Early life and career== Francis Potenza was born in [[Brooklyn]], New York in 1933.<ref name=nytimes/> He served in the [[United States army]] during the [[Korean War]].<ref name=latimes/> Potenza joined the [[New York Police Department]] (NYPD) following the war, serving as a [[Beat (police)|beat cop]] in [[Bensonhurst, Brooklyn]] in the 62nd Precinct for 20 years.<ref name="latimes" /><ref name="nydailynews" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/6697716/NYPD-62nd-Precinct|title=NYPD 62nd Precinct - New York City, New York|work=wikimapia.org|accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref> He reportedly made just six arrests during his two decades in the NYPD, believing that a lecture by the police delivered more benefits than a prison sentence.<ref name=nytimes/>
He became a [[security guard]] and moved to Las Vegas, Nevada, upon his retirement from the NYPD.<ref name=nydailynews/> He served inside [[Frank Sinatra]]'s personal [[security detail]] and as bodyguard when Sinatra performed at [[Caesars Palace]].<ref name=latimes/> He returned to New York City to take a security position at [[St. Patrick's Cathedral (New York)|St. Patrick's Cathedral]] in Manhattan.<ref name=nydailynews/>
==Role on ''Jimmy Kimmel Live!''== Potenza had worked in security for more than ten years in New York City and Las Vegas when his nephew, [[comedian]] [[Jimmy Kimmel]], asked him to join his late-night show, ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', as a regular in 2003.<ref name=latimes/><ref name=nytimes/> Potenza, who was still working security at St. Patrick's Cathedral at the time,<ref name=nydailynews/> accepted Kimmel's offer and moved to [[southern California]].<ref name=latimes/> He was introduced to audiences as Kimmel's "Uncle Frank," serving as a comic foil to the late night host.<ref name=latimes/> Potenza appeared on the show for nine years from 2003 to 2011. Uncle Frank quickly developed his own fan following, with Kimmel noting in 2007, "People can tell that Uncle Frank is the genuine article... That's why they like him."<ref name=latimes/>
In one ongoing comic piece, Potenza was teamed with his former wife (and Kimmel's aunt), Concetta ("Chippy"), for a series of tasks ranging from [[self defense]] lessons to [[dairy farming]]. Potenza was also paired with [[Guillermo Díaz (Jimmy Kimmel Live!)|Guillermo Rodriguez]], the show's parking lot security guard, and [[Veatrice Rice]], the show's security guard, for comedic effect. Rice died of cancer on January 21, 2009.<ref name=latimes/>
==Death and tributes== Potenza died from cancer in Los Angeles on August 23, 2011, aged 77.<ref name=nytimes/> He was survived by his ex-wife, three daughters, and a granddaughter.<ref name=latimes/> He was married to Chippy, for more than 28 years before their divorce. His memorial service was held in Las Vegas.<ref name=latimes/> In a [[Twitter]] message, Kimmel thanked Potenza's fans, tweeting, "Thank you for your kind words about a very kind man" and "RIP Uncle Frank, his [[comic timing]] took a lifetime to earn. Today I eat cake for him."<ref name=nydailynews/>
The show was on summer hiatus at the time of Potenza's death and was scheduled to return on September 6, 2011.<ref name=ktla>{{cite news|title=Jimmy Kimmel's Uncle Frank, Staple on 'Kimmel Show' Dies at 77|url=http://www.ktla.com/news/landing/ktla-kimmel-uncle-frank-dead,0,2611468.story|work=[[KTLA-TV]]|date=2011-08-23|accessdate=2011-09-01}}</ref> On September 6, Kimmel aired a special tribute episode to Uncle Frank, with an interview with Frank's favorite guest, [[Don Rickles]]. A caricature of Uncle Frank appears in tribute on the back cover of [[The Mighty Mighty Bosstones]]' album ''[[The Magic of Youth]]'', released on December 16, 2011 (the Bosstones' lead singer, [[Dicky Barrett]], is the announcer for ''Jimmy Kimmel Live!'').
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Potenza, Frank}} [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:New York City Police Department officers]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:American television personalities]] [[Category:Security guards]] [[Category:American army personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:People from Brooklyn]] [[Category:People from the Las Vegas Valley]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in California]] [[Category:United States Army soldiers]]

revision.text:
[[File:Wallace Spirit Photograph.png|thumb|right|Spirit photograph taken by Hudson of [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] and his mother.]] '''Frederick Augustus Hudson''' (B. CA. 1812) was a British [[Spirit photography|spirit photographer]] who was active in the 1870s.Chéroux, Clément (2004). ''The Perfect Medium: Photography and the Occult''. [[Yale University Press]]. pp. 29-44. {{ISBN|0-300-11136-3}}Buckland, Raymond (2005). ''The Spirit Book: The Encyclopedia of Clairvoyance, Channeling, and Spirit Communication''. [[Visible Ink Press]]. pp. 187-188. {{ISBN|1-57859-172-4}} ==Investigations== Hudson established his own studio in [[London]], and worked with the medium [[Georgiana Houghton]].Hill, Annette (2011). ''Paranormal Media: Audiences, Spirits and Magic in Popular Culture''. [[Routledge]]. p. 34. {{ISBN|0-415-54463-7}}Jay, Bill (1991). ''Cyanide & Spirits: An Inside-Out View of Early Photography''. Nazraeli Press. p. 20 He is credited as being the first spirit photographer in Britain.Willburn, Sarah A (2006). ''Possessed Victorians: Extra Spheres in Nineteenth-century Mystical Writings''. [[Ashgate]]. p. 58. {{ISBN|0-7546-5540-7}} According to [[Joseph McCabe]], Hudson's photographs were exposed as fraudulent in 1872 by a fellow spiritualist, William Henry Harrison.McCabe, Joseph (1920). ''Spiritualism: A Popular History from 1847''. [[Dodd, Mead and Company]]. p. 157 Hudson was also exposed by another investigator. The psychical researcher [[Simeon Edmunds]] wrote that "John Beattie, a professional photographer of note, demonstrated conclusively that his spirits were faked by a simple process of double exposure."Edmunds, Simeon (1966). ''Spiritualism: A Critical Survey''. [[Aquarian Press]]. p. 114 In 1874, [[Alfred Russel Wallace]] visited Hudson and a photograph of him with his deceased mother was produced. Wallace declared the photograph genuine, declaring "I see no escape from the conclusion that some spiritual being, acquainted with my mother's various aspects during life, produced these recognisable impressions on the plate."Wallace, Alfred Russel (1875). [https://archive.org/stream/onmiraclesmodern00wall#page/190/mode/2up ''On Miracles and Modern Spiritualism'']. London: James Burns. pp. 190-191 ==Trickery== Magic Historian [[Milbourne Christopher]] has written:
Hudson introduced spirit photography to Britain in 1872. He varied his methods through the years. Though frequently caught practicing deception, he was never arrested. Hudson at one time used a trick camera, made by a craftsman who sold conjuring apparatus. [[Harry Price]] described how the camera worked in his book, ''Confessions of a Ghost-Hunter'', published in London in 1936. When the plate slide was inserted, this action brought the paper positive of the "ghost" up against the sensitive plate. When the shutter bulb was pressed, this image and the picture of the sitter were captured on the plate. Thus a single exposure on this plate carried both images.Christopher, Milbourne (1975). ''Mediums, Mystics & the Occult''. [[Thomas Y. Crowell Co.]] pp. 115-116. {{ISBN|0-690-00476-1}}
Hudson was known to dress up as spirits or use [[double exposure]] to produce his spirit photography. Skeptical investigator [[Joe Nickell]] noted that Hudson's photographs were fraudulent. In many cases the sitter in the photographs was positioned low to the allow space for the "spirits" already pre-positioned by Hudson.Nickell, Joe (2012). ''The Science of Ghosts: Searching for Spirits of the Dead''. [[Prometheus Books]]. pp. 301-302. {{ISBN|978-1-61614-585-9}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Spiritism and Spiritualism}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hudson (photographer), Frederick}} [[Category:British photographers]] [[Category:English spiritual mediums]] [[Category:Spiritualists]] [[Category:1810s births]] [[Category:Year of death missing]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Gaëtan Dugas | image = Gaëtan Dugas.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1953|02|20}} | birth_place = [[Quebec City]], [[Quebec]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|1984|03|30|1953|02|20}} | death_place = Quebec City, Quebec, Canada | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | other_names = | known_for = Long misdescribed as "[[index case|patient zero]]" of the [[HIV/AIDS in the United States|North American AIDS epidemic]] | occupation = [[Flight attendant]] }} '''Gaëtan Dugas''' ({{IPA-fr|ɡaetɑ̃ dyɡa|lang}}; February 20, 1953 – March 30, 1984), a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[flight attendant]], was a relatively early [[HIV]] patient who once was widely regarded as "[[index case|patient zero]]" or the primary case for AIDS in the United States; his case was later found to have been only one of many that began in the 1970s, according to a September 2016 study published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]''.<ref name="BBC-October-26-2106">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/health-37767179 |title=HIV Patient Zero cleared by science |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=26 October 2016 |accessdate=26 October 2016 |first=James |last=Gallagher }}</ref><ref name="NYT 2016-10-27">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/27/health/hiv-patient-zero-genetic-analysis.html |title=H.I.V. Arrived in the U.S. Long Before ‘Patient Zero’ |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=26 October 2016 |access-date=26 October 2016 |last=McNeil |first=Donald G, Jr. }}</ref><ref name="Woroby, Watts et al 2016">{{cite journal |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature19827.html |title=1970s and ‘Patient 0’ HIV-1 genomes illuminate early HIV/AIDS history in North America |first1=Michael |last1=Worobey |author2=Thomas D. Watts |author3=Richard A. McKay |author4=Marc A. Suchard |author5=Timothy Granade |author6=Dirk E. Teuwen |author7=Beryl A. Koblin |author8=Walid Heneine |author9=Philippe Lemey |author10=Harold W. Jaffe |display-authors=2 |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=539 |pages=98–101 |date=October 26, 2016 |url-access=subscription |doi=10.1038/nature19827 |pmc=5257289 }}</ref>
In March 1984, a [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) study tracked the sexual liaisons and practices of [[gay]] and [[bisexual]] men, especially in California and New York. Dugas was code-named as "patient O" (pronounced "oh", and standing for "Out-of-California"); misconstruing of the letter "O" as 0 (zero) led to the origin of the term "patient zero."<ref name="npr.org"/><ref name="lrb"/> The extent to which HIV/AIDS was known about in the early 1980s, how it was spread, or when Dugas was diagnosed are disputed.<ref name=gtpmi>{{Cite journal|last=McKay|first=Richard A.|date=2014|title="Patient Zero":|journal=Bulletin of the History of Medicine|pages=161–194|doi=10.1353/bhm.2014.0005|issn=0007-5140|pmc=4046389|pmid=24769806}}</ref>
<!-- The following commented-out material may be salvagable, but is heavily infected with lurid typhoid-Gaeton drama, in sources that need re-evaluation of their qualification as [[WP:Reliable source]]s:
found Dugas to be the center of a network of sexual partners, which led to his being dubbed "patient zero",<ref name="Auerbach1984" /> although suspicions that he initially brought HIV to North America have been disproven.<ref name=BBC-October-26-2106/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livescience.com/56649-hiv-patient-zero-did-not-bring-virus-to-america.html|title=HIV's 'Patient Zero' Wrongly Blamed for AIDS Epidemic|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="npr.org">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/10/26/498876985/mystery-solved-how-hiv-came-to-the-u-s|title=Researchers Clear 'Patient Zero' From AIDS Origin Story|publisher=}}</ref>
Dugas traveled the world and had myriad sexual liaisons with other men.<ref name=gtpmi/><ref>[http://dailyxtra.com/ottawa/news/gaétan-dugas-and-the-aids-mary-myth Gaétan Dugas and the 'AIDS Mary' myth]"Gaétan Dugas, the gorgeous French-Canadian flight attendant who hopped cities as easily as he hopped beds."</ref> At the time, [[gay culture]] in some cultures was largely illegal, underground, and clandestine. [[Gay bars]] and [[gay bath house]]s were social settings for gay and [[closeted]] men to meet. ---> Dugas worked as a flight attendant for [[Air Canada]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archives.cbc.ca/IDC-0-13-400-2251/desastres_tragedies/sida/clip1 |title=La découverte de la maladie — Sida, les premières années |trans-title=Discovering the illness — AIDS, the first years | language=French | work=[[Radio-Canada]] |date=17 January 1992 |archivedate=August 18, 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040818070955/http://archives.cbc.ca/IDC-0-13-400-2251/desastres_tragedies/sida/clip1 }}</ref> and died in [[Quebec City]] in March 1984 as a result of [[kidney failure]] caused by AIDS-related infections.<ref>{{cite book |last=Shilts |first=Randy |authorlink=Randy Shilts |title=And The Band Played On |publisher=[[Penguin Books|Penguin]] |year=1988 |pages=439 |isbn=0-14-011130-1}}</ref>
=="Patient Zero" hypothesis== [[File:AIDS index case graph.svg|upright=1.5|thumb|A 1984 paper<ref name="Auerbach1984"/> linked 40 AIDS patients by sexual contact. Of those patients, Dugas was the first to experience an onset of symptoms of AIDS. In the above graph, Dugas is represented by the number 0. Because Dugas was very forthcoming in helping researchers, Michael Worobey concludes there may be [[sampling bias|ascertainment bias]] in the study.<ref name="npr.org">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2016/10/26/498876985/mystery-solved-how-hiv-came-to-the-u-s |title=Researchers Clear 'Patient Zero' From AIDS Origin Story |last=Doucleff |first=Michaeleen|date=October 26, 2016 |publisher=[[NPR]] }}</ref>]] A study published in ''[[The American Journal of Medicine]]'' in 1984 traced many early [[HIV]] infections to an unnamed infected gay male flight attendant.<ref name="Auerbach1984">{{cite journal |last1=Auerbach |first1=D.M. |author2=W.W. Darrow |author3=H.W. Jaffe |author4=J.W. Curran |title=Cluster of cases of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Patients linked by sexual contact |journal=[[The American Journal of Medicine]] |volume=76 |issue=3 |pages=487–92 |year=1984 |doi=10.1016/0002-9343(84)90668-5 |pmid=6608269 |deadurl=no }}<!--|accessdate=March 3, 2014--></ref> Initially, however, the CDC researcher, who was studying cases in Los Angeles, California, referred to Dugas not as "patient zero", but as "patient O", the letter "O" standing for "outside California".<ref name="npr.org"/>
Dugas is featured prominently in [[Randy Shilts]]'s book ''[[And the Band Played On]]: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic'' (1987), which documents the outbreak of the [[HIV/AIDS in the United States|AIDS epidemic in the United States]]. Shilts portrays Dugas as having almost sociopathic behavior by allegedly intentionally infecting, or at least recklessly endangering, others with the virus. Dugas is described as being a charming, handsome sexual athlete who, according to his own estimation, averaged hundreds of sex partners per year. He claimed to have had over 2,500 sexual partners across North America since becoming sexually active in 1972.<ref>{{cite book |last=Gladwell |first=Malcolm |authorlink=Malcolm Gladwell |title=[[The Tipping Point]] |publisher=[[Little, Brown and Company]] |year=2000 |pages=21 |isbn=0-316-34662-4 }}</ref> In [[David France (writer)|David France]]'s 2016 book ''[[How to Survive a Plague]]'', Shilts's editor expressed his regret for having "made a conscious decision to vilify Dugas in the book and publicity campaign in order to spur sales."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I31ODAAAQBAJ&lpg=PT97&dq=gaëtan%20dugas&pg=PT79#v=onepage&q=dugas&f=false |title=How to Survive a Plague: The Story of How Activists and Scientists Tamed AIDS |first=David |last=France |authorlink=David France (writer) |publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Pan Macmillan]] |date=December 1, 2016 |isbn=978-1-5098-3941-4 |page=PT79 |accessdate=December 28, 2016 }}</ref>
Genetic analysis historically provided some support for the [[Index case|Patient Zero]] theory, in which Dugas was believed to be part of a cluster of homosexual men who traveled frequently, were extremely sexually active, and died of AIDS at a very early stage in the epidemic.<ref name="Kuiken et al 2000">{{cite journal |last1=Kuiken |first1=C |last2=Thakallapalli |first2=R |last3=Esklid |first3=A |last4=de Ronde |first4=A |title=Genetic analysis reveals epidemiologic patterns in the spread of human immunodeficiency virus |journal=[[American Journal of Epidemiology]] |volume=152 |issue=9 |pages=814–22 |date=November 1, 2000 |doi=10.1093/aje/152.9.814 |doi-access=free |pmid=11085392 |deadurl=no }}<!--|accessdate=March 3, 2014--></ref>
==Re-examination of "Patient Zero" hypothesis== {{see also|History of HIV/AIDS}} A number of authorities have since voiced reservations about the implications of the CDC's Patient Zero study and characterizations of Dugas as being responsible for bringing HIV to cities like Los Angeles and San Francisco. In the Patient Zero study, the average length of time between sexual contact and the onset of symptoms was {{fraction|10|1|2}} months.<ref name="Auerbach1984" /> While Shilts's book does not make such an allegation, the rumor that Dugas was the principal disseminator of the virus became widespread.<ref name="lrb"/> In 1988, Andrew R. Moss published an opposing view in ''[[The New York Review of Books]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last=Moss |first=Andrew R. |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/4227 |title=AIDS Without End |work=[[The New York Review of Books]] |date=December 8, 1988 |accessdate=December 2, 2006 }}</ref>
In 2016, a group of researchers led by [[evolutionary biology|evolutionary biologist]] Dr. Michael Worobey conducted a genetic study that looked at blood samples taken from gay and bisexual men in 1978 and 1979 as part of a [[hepatitis B]] study, and based on the results of the data, concluded that Dugas was not the source of the virus in the U.S. "On the family tree of the virus, Dugas fell in the middle, not at the beginning."<ref name="Straube 2016-05-16">{{cite web |url=https://www.poz.com/article/mapping-early-aids-us |title=Mapping Out Early AIDS in the U.S. |first=Trenton |last=Straube |date=May 16, 2016 |work=[[POZ (magazine)|POZ]] }}</ref> "Beliefs about Patient Zero," Worobey concludes, "are unsupported by scientific data."<ref name="Straube 2016-05-16"/> Worobey's paper, published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' in October 2016, finds "neither biological nor historical evidence that he was the primary case in the US or for [[subtypes of HIV|subtype]] B as a whole."<ref name="BBC-October-26-2106"/><ref name="NYT 2016-10-27"/><ref name="Woroby, Watts et al 2016"/>
A study by historian Richard McKay of Cambridge and others identified several causes for the Patient Zero myth. During early CDC analysis of cases in California, patient 057 (Dugas) was nicknamed patient "O" for "outside the area", but this was interpreted by others as Patient Zero. Dugas was particularly helpful in tracing his network of partners, providing names and addresses for many of them, which was further expanded because others remembered his distinctive name.<ref name="lrb">{{cite news |last1=Crewe |first1=Tom |title=Here was a plague |url=https://www.lrb.co.uk/v40/n18/tom-crewe/here-was-a-plague |accessdate=29 September 2018 |publisher=London Review of Books |date=27 September 2018}}</ref> Although many of the patients analyzed reported in excess of 1000 sexual partners, most remembered "only a handful" of names, making their contacts to other cases more difficult to trace.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-10/uoc-nr102416.php |title=New research reveals accidental making of 'Patient Zero' myth during 1980s AIDS crisis |publisher=[[University of Cambridge]] |date=October 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="Woroby, Watts et al 2016"/>
Dr. Robert M. Grant, an AIDS researcher at the [[University of California]], has stated: "No one wants to be the Patient Zero of their village. But this may be helpful because it says, ‘Just because you are the first to be diagnosed doesn’t mean you started the epidemic.’ "<ref name="NYT 2016-10-27"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[Timeline of early HIV/AIDS cases]] * [[Timeline of HIV/AIDS]] * ''[[Zero Patience]]''
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://gay.hfxns.org/GaetanDugas Halifax Rainbow Encyclopedia page for Dugas]—he lived in Halifax for several years. * {{Find a Grave|9905570}} * [http://3030.aidsvancouver.org/1983/ AidsVancouver] - archive footage of Gaetan Dugas speaking at an Aids Vancouver forum (beginning at ~5:45) * [http://science.sciencemag.org/content/351/6277/1013 ‘Patient Zero’ no more] - study reported in Science Magazine (Vol. 351, Issue 6277, pp. 1013), American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) (Article)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dugas, Gaetan}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:Gay men]] [[Category:LGBT people from Canada]] [[Category:AIDS-related deaths in Canada]] [[Category:Flight attendants]] [[Category:History of HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Index cases]] [[Category:Canadian people of French descent]] [[Category:French Quebecers]] [[Category:People from Quebec City]] [[Category:Air Canada people]] [[Category:Deaths from kidney failure]] [[Category:People with HIV/AIDS]]
