revision.text:
{{Infobox State Representative | image = | name=Gilbert Louis Dupre Sr. | image name= | office=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for St. Landry Parish]] | term_start=1888 | term_end=1890 | term_start2=1913 | term_end2=1932 | preceded2=A. H. Garland | succeeded2= | office3=District Judge for St. Landry Parish | term_start3=1896 | term_end3=1912 | birth_date={{Birth date|1858|9|20}} | birth_place=[[St. Landry Parish, Louisiana|St. Landry Parish]]
[[Louisiana]], USA | death_date={{death date and age|1946|12|18|1858|9|}} | death_place= | resting_place=Myrtle Grove Cemetery in Opelousas, Louisiana | spouse=Julia Estillette Dupré (married 1881-1944, her death) | children=Marie Lucile Dupré
Gilbert L. Dupré Jr.
Fannie Estilette Dupré Pavy
Ethel May Dupré Litten | parents=Lucius J. and Caroline Vanhille Dupré | profession=[[Lawyer]] | religion=[[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholic]] | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | alma_mater=[[Home schooling]]
Private study of law in office of St. Landry Parish district clerk | branch=Louisiana State Militia | battles= | footnotes= }} '''Gilbert Louis Dupré Sr.''' (September 20, 1858 – December 18, 1946),{{cite web|url=https://findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Dupre&GSbyrel=all&GSdyrel=all&GSst=20&GScnty=1157&GScntry=4&GSob=n&GSsr=161&GRid=132676391&df=all&|title=Gilbert Louis Dupré, Sr., in ''History of Louisiana'', (Vol. 2)|author=[[Henry E. Chambers]]|publisher=The American Historical Society, Inc.|location=[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]|pages=378–379|date=1925|accessdate=February 25, 2017}} was a self-educated [[lawyer]] and [[Louisiana House of Representatives|state representative]] from [[Opelousas, Louisiana|Opelousas]], [[Louisiana]], known for his initial political opposition to [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Huey Long|Huey Pierce Long Jr.]] He held his state House seat from 1913 to 1932.{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf|title=Membership in the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812-2020|publisher=[[Louisiana House of Representatives]]|accessdate=February 25, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006105414/http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf|archivedate=October 6, 2014|df=}} A native of [[St. Landry Parish, Louisiana|St. Landry Parish]] in [[South Louisiana]], he maintained his legal office for many years in [[Opelousas, Louisiana|Opelousas]]. In his last year in office, Dupré, by then an elderly deaf man, spoke out against the Long intra-party challenger, [[Dudley LeBlanc]] of [[Abbeville, Louisiana|Abbeville]] through the Long newspaper, the ''[[Louisiana Progress]]''. ==Biography== Dupré was born into an established [[French people|French]]-American family, the son of Lucius Jacques Dupré (1822–1869) and the former Caroline Victoire Vanhille (1826–1896). His great-grandfather, [[Jacques Dupré]], was a pioneer of St. Landry Parish who served as a [[National Republican Party|National Republican]] [[governor of Louisiana]] from 1830 to 1831 and in the [[Louisiana State Senate]] during the 1830s and 1840s. Gilbert was only ten when his father, Lucius, who was a law graduate of the [[University of Virginia]] and a member of the former [[Confederate Congress]], died. There was no money for Gilbert's education; so he was self-educated in the law while he worked first in the office of the St. Landry Parish clerk of court. He was admitted to the bar in 1880 and established his law office in Opelousas. In 1887, Dupré was a member of the Louisiana state militia and was on active duty at the time of a riot in [[Morgan City, Louisiana|Morgan City]] in [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana|St. Mary Parish]]. He was a member of the [[Masonic lodge]], the [[Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks]], and the [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholic Church]].{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/132676391|title=Gilbert Louis Dupré|publisher=''St. Landry Trade Review''|date=December 1896|accessdate=March 7, 2015}} From 1888 to 1992 and again from 1913, to fill the seat vacated by A. H. Garland, who left the state, until 1932, Dupré was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] member of the Louisiana House of Representatives.{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |title=Membership in the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812- Current: St. Landry Parish |publisher=house.louisiana.gov |accessdate=March 6, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006105414/http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df= }} He served as a state district court judge by election from 1896 to 1900 and by appointment in 1914. He was elected judge in 1916, 1920, and 1924, while he also served in the part-time legislative post. Such dual office-holding is no longer permitted. Judge Dupré, as he was long known, was a member of the Louisiana Constitutional Convention of 1921. In his second stint in the legislature, his successors included his son-in-law, [[Felix Octave Pavy]], a prominent St. Landry Parish physician and an uncle by marriage of Dr. [[Carl Weiss]], the [[Assassination|assassin]] of [[U.S. Senator]] [[Huey Long|Huey Pierce Long, Jr.]] The editor of the former ''New Orleans Item'' referred to Representative Dupré's steadfast opposition to tax increases:
There was a statesman in [[Tennessee]] who attributed his popularity to the fact that he had never voted for a tax or against an appropriation. We might almost say of Judge Dupré that we do not recall his ever having voted for a tax increase, salary increase, or for an increased appropriation. The position of the twelfth man in opposition to eleven stubborn jurors is one which the judge is not afraid to take in a world which loves to have unanimous action and where kickers are generally made uncomfortable.Quoted in [[Henry E. Chambers]], ''A History of Louisiana'', (vol. 2) ([[Chicago]] and [[New York City]]: The American Historical Society, Inc., 1925), pp. 378-379
In 1881, Dupré married Julia B. Estilette (1860–1944) of Opelousas, the daughter of his law partner, [[E. D. Estilette]]. She was born in [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]], [[Connecticut]], where her father was attending [[Yale University]]. E. D. Estilette was a judge and in 1876 the [[Speaker of the Louisiana House of Representatives]]. The couple had four children, including twin daughters, a son, and a third daughter. He was a member of the [[Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks]]. Dupré outlived his wife by two years. They are interred along with other family members at the Myrtle Grove Cemetery in Opelousas. To retaliate against Dupré, Long had a hole drilled in the roof directly above Dupre's office in the [[Old Louisiana State Capitol]] to punish Dupré for the lawmaker's opposition to a new capitol building. When he demanded that Governor Huey Long repair the problem at once, Long said that he would do so only if Dupré would vote for the planned new [[Louisiana State Capitol]] building, to be built in [[skyscraper]] format. When Dupré refused to commit his vote, Long told him, "Die, damn you, in the faith!"[[Huey Pierce Long, Jr.]], ''Every Man a King: The Autobiography of Huey P. Long'' ([[New Orleans]]: National Book Club, Inc., 1933), p. 239. Long then noted that Dupré "was much amused and almost came over." == References == {{Reflist}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Louisiana|Law|Politics|Christianity}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |before=Aurle Arnaud
Albert Guidry
John C. Lyons
Placide Robin | title=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for St. Landry Parish]] '''Gilbert Louis Dupré, Sr.'''
(alongside Albert Guidry and Dr. G. C. Martin) | years=1888 – 1892 | after=Nap McBride
George Pulford
Adolph Stagg
Henry D. Larcade, Jr.}} {{succession box |before=A. H. Garland | title=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for St. Landry Parish]] '''Gilbert Louis Dupré, Sr.'''
(alongside eight other members over nineteen years) | years=1913 – 1932 | after=[[Felix Octave Pavy]]
Isom J. Guillory
George K. Perrault}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dupré, Gilbert}} [[Category:1858 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:Louisiana lawyers]] [[Category:Members of the Louisiana House of Representatives]] [[Category:Louisiana state court judges]] [[Category:People from Opelousas, Louisiana]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Cajun people]] [[Category:Louisiana Democrats]] [[Category:Burials in Louisiana]] [[Category:Catholics from Louisiana]]

:''J. Neil Schulman should not be confused with fellow Prometheus Award winner, [[L. Neil Smith]]'' {{Infobox writer | name = J. Neil Schulman | image = J Neil Schulman by Arturo Ruggeroli.jpg | imagesize = | caption = J. Neil Schulman | pseudonym = | birth_name = Joseph Neil Schulman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|4|16|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Forest Hills, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Novelist, filmmaker, actor, journalist, composer, publisher. | nationality = American | period = 20th-century, 21st-century. | genre = [[Libertarian science fiction]], [[comedy]]. | subject = | movement = | influences = [[Robert A. Heinlein]]{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
[[Ayn Rand]]
[[C. S. Lewis]]
[[Anthony Burgess]]
[[Alfred Hitchcock]]
[[Samuel Edward Konkin III]]
[[Milton Friedman]]
[[Murray Rothbard]] | influenced = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.jneilschulman.com}} }} '''Joseph Neil Schulman''' ({{IPAc-en|'|ʃ|uː|l|m|ə|n}}; born April 16, 1953){{cite web|url=http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/ea.cgi?665|title=Summary Bibliography: J. Neil Schulman|publisher=}} is an [[United States|American]] novelist who wrote ''[[Alongside Night]]'' (published 1979) and ''[[The Rainbow Cadenza]]'' (published 1983) which both received the [[Prometheus Award]], a [[libertarian science fiction]] award. His third novel, ''Escape from Heaven'', was also a finalist for the 2002 Prometheus Award. ==Biography== Schulman was born in [[Forest Hills, Queens]]. He is the author of nine other books currently in print, including a short story collection, ''Nasty, Brutish, and Short Stories'', ''Stopping Power: Why 70 Million Americans Own Guns'', and ''The Robert Heinlein Interview and Other Heinleiniana''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pulpless.com/jneil/books.html|title=Books by J. Neil Schulman|publisher=}} He is writer of the ''[[The Twilight Zone (1985 TV series)|Twilight Zone]]'' episode "[[Profile in Silver]]", first broadcast on CBS March 7, 1986. From "About J. Neil Schulman" in ''The Fractal Man'': J. Neil Schulman is an award-winning writer, filmmaker, journalist, and entrepreneur whom the Wall Street Journal called a pioneer of electronic publishing in 1989. His 1979 Prometheus-Hall-of-Fame novel Alongside Night—endorsed by Milton Friedman, Anthony Burgess, and Ron Paul—projected the economic meltdown and was Freedom Book of the Month for May, 2009. Alongside Night was his second feature film as writer/producer/director/actor, and starred Kevin Sorbo, Jake Busey, Gary Graham, Tim Russ, Garrett Wang, Mara Marini, and Said Faraj. After a red-carpet Beverly Hills premiere it released in a limited theatrical run in 2014, and is now available on Amazon Video & Prime along with his award-winning 2008 comic thriller, Lady Magdalene's, starring Nichelle Nichols. His latest novel is the science-fiction alternate-timeline romp, The Fractal Man, released by Steve Heller Publishing in May 2018 as a $0.99 Amazon Kindle. Schulman is currently at work on his fifth novel, The Metronome Misnomer. The title comes from a fractal version of the author in The Fractal Man, who wrote a book of that title in an alternate timeline. His 1983 novel, The Rainbow Cadenza, won the Prometheus Award, was adapted into a Laserium show, and Robert A. Heinlein told the 1983 L-5 Society, "Every libertarian should read it!" His 2002 novel Escape from Heaven has been compared to Mark Twain. His short story “Day of Atonement” appeared in the Prometheus-award-winning Tor book Free Space, and his short story “The Repossessed” led off Carol Serling's anthology Adventures in the Twilight Zone. Both are reprinted in his short-story collection, Nasty, Brutish, and Short Stories. Schulman scripted the CBS revived Twilight Zone episode, "Profile in Silver," about a future historian who creates a disastrous alternate timeline when he time travels back to November 22, 1963 and prevents JFK's assassination. He taught a graduate course on electronic publishing for The New School, has written for popular magazines and newspapers including New Libertarian, Mondo Cult, National Review, Reason, the Los Angeles Times, and Reader's Digest, and monographs ranging from animal rights, informational property rights, and medicalization of criminology have been widely anthologized by academic presses. His other books include Stopping Power: Why 70 Million Americans Own Guns, endorsed by Charlton Heston and Dennis Prager, Self Control Not Gun Control endorsed by Walter Williams, and The Robert Heinlein Interview and Other Heinleiniana, which Virginia Heinlein said "should be on the shelves of everyone interested in science fiction." His latest printed book is The Heartmost Desire which includes two other of his books available as Amazon Kindles: Unchaining the Human Heart – A Revolutionary Manifesto (his answer to Mao's “Little Red Book”) and I Met God – God Without Religion, Scripture or Faith (his answer both to atheists like he used to be and to dogmatic religious zealots). His Kindle book J. Neil Schulman's The Book of Words collects much of his humorous and controversial writings. He's recipient of the James Madison Award from the Second Amendment Foundation, the Samuel Edward Konkin III Memorial Chauntecleer by the Karl Hess Club, and the Sovereign Award from the Libertopia convention. Full bio at http://www.pulpless.com/jneil/jnsbio.html {{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Fractal-Man-J-Neil-Schulman-ebook/dp/B07D994VRQ/|title=The Fractal Man About J. Neil Schulman|publisher=}} == Books == Schulman is author of:{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/J.-Neil-Schulman/e/B000APX214/|title=Amazon.com search for J. Neil Schulman |website=www.amazon.com}} * ''Self Control Not Gun Control'' (Synapse-Centurion, 1995; Pulpless.Com 1999) * ''Profile in Silver and Other Screenwritings'' (Pulpless.Com, 1999) * ''The Frame of the Century?'' (Pulpless.Com, 1999) * ''The Heartmost Desire'' (Pulpless.Com, 2013) * ''Unchaining the Human Heart -- A Revolutionary Manifesto'' (Pulpless.Com, 2017) * ''I Met God -- God without Religion, Scripture, or Faith'' (Pulpless.Com, 2017) * ''Atheist to Believer'' (Pulpless.Com, 2017) * ''J. Neil Schulman's The Book of Words'' (Pulpless.Com, 2017) * ''The Fractal Man'' (Steve Heller Publishing, 2018)https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07D994VRQ/ * ''Origitent: Why Original Content Is Property'' (Steve Heller Publishing, 2018)https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07DRQ9NWC == Literary Status == On ''[[Alongside Night]]'' "I received Alongside Night at noon today. It is now eight in the evening and I just finished it. I think I am entitled to some dinner now as I had no lunch. The unputdownability of the book ensured that. It is a remarkable and original story, and the picture it presents of an inflation- crippled America on the verge of revolution is all too acceptable. I wish, and so will many novelists, that I, or they, had thought of the idea first. A thrilling novel, crisply written, that fires the imagination as effectively as it stimulates the feelings." -- [[Anthony Burgess]] https://www.amazon.com/Alongside-Night-J-Neil-Schulman/dp/1584451203 "An absorbing novel--science fiction, yet also a cautionary tale with a disturbing resemblance to past history and future possibilities." --[[Milton Friedman]] On ''[[The Rainbow Cadenza]]'' "I found it absolutely fascinating ... A splendid book." --[[Colin Wilson]] "An original and thoughtful book which raises questions that have not appeared in fiction before." --[[Gregory Benford]] "Every libertarian should read it. It should win the Prometheus Award." --[[Robert A. Heinlein]], at the 1983 L-5 Society Conference, to Libertarian Futurist Society Chairman Michael Grossberg On ''Escape from Heaven'' "Wild, irreverent, a hoot. Any other civilization would have burned Schulman at the stake. Did they know something we don't?" -- [[David Brin]] On ''Self Control Not Gun Control'' "Schulman interestingly and insightfully raises a number of liberty-related issues that we ignore at the nation's peril. His ideas are precisely those that helped make our country the destination of those seeking liberty. The book's title says it all: personal responsibility, not laws and prohibitions, is the mark of a civil society." --[[Walter E. Williams]] == Filmmaking == Schulman was the writer, director, executive producer (along with [[Nichelle Nichols]]) of the movie, ''[[Lady Magdalene's]]''{{IMDb title|tt0783538|Lady Magdalene's}} which was produced by Schulman's own company Jesulu Productions. The movie won three film-festival awards: "Best Cutting Edge Film" at the 2008 San Diego Black Film Festival, "Audience Choice – Feature-Length Narrative Film" at the 2008 Cinema City International Film Festival held on the Universal Hollywood Citywalk,{{cite web|url=http://www.lasplash.com/publish/Film_106/Cinema_City_International_Film_Festival_Review_printer.php|title=Cinema City International Film Festival Review - A Savior of Short Films - Splash Magazines - Los Angeles|publisher=}} and "Special Jury Prize for Libertarian Ideals" at the 2011 Anthem Film Festival/FreedomFest held at Bally's Las Vegas.{{cite web|url=http://anthemfilmfestival.com|title=Home|publisher=}} In 2013 Schulman completed production on a feature-film of ''Alongside Night'',{{IMDb title|tt1667061|Alongside Night (2014)}} starring [[Kevin Sorbo]], [[Jake Busey]], [[Tim Russ]], [[Garrett Wang]], [[Mara Marini]], and [[Gary Graham]].http://www.dujpepperman.com/jesulu/alongsidenight/AN_Credits.html The movie premiered in 2014{{cite web|url=https://www.laemmle.com/films/38254|title=Alongside Night - Laemmle.com|website=www.laemmle.com}} and had a limited theatrical release.{{cite web|title=Alongside Night|url=https://www.tugg.com/titles/Alongside-Night|website=www.tugg.com|accessdate=30 July 2017}} It was released for streaming on [[iTunes]], [[Amazon Video]] and [[Amazon Prime]] and as a Blu-ray/DVD combo pack.https://www.amazon.com/Alongside-Night-Blu-ray-Combo-Pack/dp/B0113NVV1Y The film is rated 2.7 out of 5 on Amazon.https://www.amazon.com/Alongside-Night-Kevin-Sorbo/dp/B0163BSRWW/ ==See also== * [[Agorism]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.jneilschulman.com Official Website] *{{IMDb name|776090}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schulman, J. Neil}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:21st-century American novelists]] [[Category:American libertarians]] [[Category:American anarcho-capitalists]] [[Category:American male novelists]] [[Category:American science fiction writers]] [[Category:American male screenwriters]] [[Category:Former atheists and agnostics]] [[Category:Prometheus Award winners]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male short story writers]] [[Category:20th-century American short story writers]] [[Category:21st-century American short story writers]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]] [[Category:21st-century American male writers]] [[Category:Screenwriters from California]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = John E. Mack |image = John E. Mack.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = John Edward Mack |birth_date = {{Birth date|1929|10|04|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], US |death_date = {{Death date and age|2004|09|27|1929|10|04|mf=y}} |death_place = [[London]], England |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = American |other_names = |known_for = [[Child psychology]]
[[Adolescent psychology]]
[[Psychology of religion]] |education = M.D. |alma_mater = [[Oberlin College]], [[Harvard Medical School]] |employer = |occupation = Professor, Psychiatrist, writer |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |spouse = Sally (Stahl) Mack |children = Daniel, Kenneth, and Tony |parents = Edward C. Mack, Ruth P. Mack |relations = Mary Lee Ingbar (half-sister) |awards = [[Pulitzer Prize]] |website = [http://www.johnemackinstitute.org The John E Mack Institute] }} '''Professor John Edward Mack''' M.D. (October 4, 1929 – September 27, 2004) was an American [[psychiatrist]], writer, and professor and department head at [[Harvard Medical School]]. In 1976, Mack won the [[Pulitzer Prize]] for his book ''A Prince of Our Disorder'' on [[T.E. Lawrence]]. Mack's clinical expertise at Harvard was in [[child psychology]], [[adolescent psychology]], and the [[psychology of religion]]. He was also known as a leading researcher on the psychology of [[teenage suicide]] and [[drug addiction]], and he later became a researcher in the psychology of [[alien abduction]] experiences.{{cite news |last=Feeney |first=Mark |title=Pulitzer Winner is Killed in Accident |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=September 29, 2004}} ==Early life, Education and Military Service== Mack was born in [[New York City]], to an academic, [[German Jewish]] family.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1472937/John-E-Mack.html John E Mack] Telegraph Obituary, 30 Sep 2004 His father, the historian Edward Clarence Mack (1904-1973), was a professor at [[City College of New York|CUNY]], while his mother Eleanor Liebmann Mack (1905-1930) died while John was an infant. After his mother died, his father remarried the economist Ruth P. Mack, through which he had a half-sister, Mary Lee Ingbar, a pioneer of computer analysis who became a professor at [[Dartmouth College]] and [[University of Massachusetts Medical School]].[https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2009/10/mary-lee-ingbar-dies-at-83 Mary Lee Ingbar, pioneer in field of health economics, dies at 83]The Harvard Gazette, October 15, 2009 Growing up, his father would read the Bible to John and his sister, but as a work of culture or literature. Mack graduated from the [[Horace Mann School|Horace Mann-Lincoln School]] in 1947 and [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from [[Oberlin College|Oberlin]] in 1951, and received his medical doctorate degree ''cum laude'' from [[Harvard Medical School]] in 1955. Mack subsequently interned at the Massachusetts General Hospital and trained as a psychiatrist at the Massachusetts Mental Health Center. In 1959, Mack joined the [[US Air Force]], serving as a [[medic]] in [[Japan]], where he rose to the rank of captain. In 1961 he returned from military service in Japan, continuing at the Massachusetts Mental Health Center and Boston Psychoanalytic Society and Institute receiving certification in child and adult [[psychoanalysis]] and [[psychotherapy]]. From 1964 Mack returned to Harvard Medical School, becoming a full professor at Harvard in 1972, and then becoming Head of the Department of Psychiatry at Harvard Medical School, where he continued to work until his death. Mack published over 150 scientific articles and eleven books in his career. As department head at Harvard Medical School, he worked primarily in the field of child and adolescent psychology. He worked on treating suicidal patients, and published research on [[heroin addiction]].''Heroin Use as an Attempt To Cope: Clinical Observations'', EDWARD J. KHANTZIAN , JOHN E. MACK , and ALAN F. SCHATZBERG, The American Journal of Psychiatry, Volume 131 Issue 2 The dominant theme of his life's work at Harvard had been the exploration of how one's perceptions of the world affect one's relationships. He addressed this issue of "[[world view]]" on the individual level in his early clinical explorations of dreams, nightmares and teen suicide, and in ''A Prince of Our Disorder'', his biographical study of the life of British officer [[T. E. Lawrence]], for which he received the [[Pulitzer Prize for Biography or Autobiography|Pulitzer Prize for Biography]] in 1977.Mack 1976 == Activism during the Cold War == In the 1980s, Mack interviewed many international political figures as part of his research into the root causes of the [[Cold War]], including former United States President [[Jimmy Carter]] and the "father of the [[Thermonuclear weapon|hydrogen bomb]]", [[Edward Teller]]. Mack, together with luminaries such as [[Carl Sagan]] and other [[Physicians for Social Responsibility]] (the United States affiliate of [[International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War]]) promoted the elimination of nuclear weapons and an end to the simmering conflict between the United States and the [[Soviet Union]]. Emboldened by the organization's receipt of the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] in 1985, Mack, Sagan, and 700 other academics walked upon the grounds of the [[Nevada Test Site]] in the summer of 1986, setting a civil disobedience record for that nuclear weapons testing facility.{{cite journal |last=Cevoli |first=Cathy |title=Putting It On The Line In Nevada |url=http://johnemackinstitute.org/1986/07/putting-it-on-the-line-in-nevada/ | journal=Nuclear Times |date=July–August 1986 |pages=36–37}} ==The psychology of alien abduction phenomenon== In the early 1990s, Mack commenced a decade-plus psychological study of 200 men and women who reported recurrent [[alien abduction|alien encounter]] experiences. Such encounters had seen some limited attention from academic figures, [[R. Leo Sprinkle]] perhaps being the earliest, in the 1960s. Mack, however, remains probably the most esteemed academic to have studied the subject.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} He initially suspected that such persons were suffering from [[Mental disorder|mental illness]], but when no obvious pathologies were present in the persons he interviewed, his interest was piqued. Following encouragement from longtime friend [[Thomas Kuhn]], who predicted that the subject might be controversial, but urged Mack to collect data and ignore prevailing materialist, dualist and "either/or" analysis, Mack began concerted study and interviews. Many of those he interviewed reported that their encounters had affected the way they regarded the world, including producing a heightened sense of [[spirituality]] and environmental concern.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} Mack was somewhat more guarded in his investigations and interpretations of the abduction phenomenon than were earlier researchers. Literature professor Terry Matheson writes that "On balance, Mack does present as fair-minded an account as has been encountered to date, at least as these abduction narratives go."Matheson 1998, p. 251. In a 1994 interview, Jeffrey Mishlove stated that Mack seemed "inclined to take these [abduction] reports at face value". Mack replied by saying "Face value I wouldn't say. I take them seriously. I don't have a way to account for them."{{cite web |title=Human Encounters with Aliens - Part 1: Abductions and the Western Paradigm |url=http://www.intuition.org/txt/mack1.htm |work=Intuition Network |date= |access-date=September 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926222933/http://www.intuition.org/txt/mack1.htm |archivedate=September 26, 2011 |df= }} Similarly, the BBC quoted Mack as saying, "I would never say, yes, there are aliens taking people. [But] I would say there is a compelling powerful phenomenon here that I can't account for in any other way, that's mysterious. Yet I can't know what it is but it seems to me that it invites a deeper, further inquiry." Mack noted that there was a worldwide history of visionary experiences, especially in pre-[[industrialisation|industrial]] societies. One example is the [[vision quest]] common to some [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] cultures. Only fairly recently in [[Western culture]], notes Mack, have such visionary events been interpreted as aberrations or as mental illness. Mack suggested that abduction accounts might best be considered as part of this larger tradition of visionary encounters.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} His interest in the spiritual or transformational aspects of people's alien encounters, and his suggestion that the experience of alien contact itself may be more transcendent than physical in nature — yet nonetheless real — set him apart from many of his contemporaries, such as [[Budd Hopkins]], who advocated the physical reality of aliens.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} His later research broadened into the general consideration of the merits of an expanded notion of reality, one which allows for experiences that may not fit the Western materialist paradigm, yet deeply affect people's lives. His second (and final) book on the alien encounter experience, ''Passport to the Cosmos: Human Transformation and Alien Encounters'' (1999), was as much a philosophical treatise connecting the themes of spirituality and modern world-views as it was the culmination of his work with the "experiencers" of alien encounters, to whom the book is dedicated.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ==Investigation by Harvard for his work on "alien abduction" cases== {{Quote box | width = 320px | align = right | quote = "John addressed my very large class, and was forthright, charming, intelligent, and disarmingly honest about what he knew and did not know. His humanity, compassion and solid science made themselves felt in that classroom... Because of the nature of his work, he made enemies in his profession, and in academia. But by his behaviour during the Harvard debacle, he proved himself to be tougher, more rigorous academically, and more the gentleman than political elements of that body of learning had themselves evinced. He won; they did not." | source = —[[Stephen Geller]], 2004[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/oct/05/guardianobituaries.obituaries1 John Mack]The Guardian, John James, Tue 5 Oct 2004 }} In May 1994, the Dean of Harvard Medical School, Daniel C. Tosteson, appointed a committee of peers to confidentially review Mack's clinical care and clinical investigation of the people who had shared their alien encounters with him (some of their cases were written of in Mack's 1994 book ''Abduction''). Angela Hind wrote, "It was the first time in Harvard's history that a tenured professor was subjected to such an investigation."{{cite web |last1=Hind |first1=Angela |title=Alien thinking |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/4071124.stm |publisher=BBC |accessdate=November 20, 2018 |date=June 8, 2005}} The committee chairman was [[Arnold S. Relman|Arnold "Budd" Relman, M.D.]], a Professor of Medicine and of Social Medicine at Harvard Medical School who served as editor of ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine]]''. According to [[Daniel Sheehan (attorney)|Daniel P. Sheehan]], one of Mack's attorneys, the committee's draft report suggested that "To communicate, in any way whatsoever, to a person who has reported a ‘close encounter’ with an extraterrestrial life form that this experience might well have been real ... is professionally irresponsible.”http://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/klass_files_volume_32/ Upon the public revelation of the existence of the committee (inadvertently revealed during the solicitation of witnesses for Mack's defense, ten months into the process), questions arose from the academic community (including Harvard Professor of Law [[Alan Dershowitz]]) regarding the validity of an investigation of a tenured professor who was not suspected of ethics violations or professional misconduct. Concluding the fourteen-month investigation, Harvard then issued a statement stating that the Dean had "reaffirmed Dr. Mack's academic freedom to study what he wishes and to state his opinions without impediment," concluding "Dr. Mack remains a member in good standing of the Harvard Faculty of Medicine." (Mack was [[censure]]d in the committee's report for what they believed were methodological errors, but Dean Tosteson took no action based on the committee's assessment.) He had received legal help from Roderick MacLeish and Daniel Sheehan,[http://danielpsheehan.com danielpsheehan.com] (of the [[New York Times Co. v. United States|Pentagon Papers]] case){{cite web |title=Daniel P Sheehan, Legal Strategist and Constitutional Attorney |url=http://www.danielpsheehan.com |work=www.danielpsheehan.net |access-date=2011-09-01}} and the support of [[Laurance Rockefeller]], who also funded Mack's non-profit organization for four consecutive years at $250,000 per year.{{cite web |last=Thompson |first=Paul B. |title=The Rockefeller UFO Report, or, How a Millionaire and a Socialite New Ager are Trying to Influence World Leaders about UFOs |url=http://www.parascope.com/nb/rockyufo.htm |year=1996 |work=www.parascope.com |publisher=ParaScope, Inc. |access-date=2011-09-01}} ==Death== On Monday, September 27, 2004 while in London to lecture at a T. E. Lawrence Society-sponsored conference, Mack was killed by a drunken driver heading west on [[Totteridge|Totteridge Lane]]. He was walking home alone, after a dinner with friends, when he was struck at 11:25 p.m. near the junction of Totteridge Lane and Longland Drive. He lost consciousness at the scene of the accident and was pronounced dead shortly thereafter. The driver, Raymond Czechowski, an IT manager, was arrested at the scene, and later entered a plea of guilty by careless driving while under the influence of alcohol. Mack's family requested leniency for the suspect Czechowski in a letter to the [[Wood Green]] Crown Court. "Although this was a tragic event for our family," the letter reads, "we feel [the accused's] behavior was neither malicious nor intentional, and we have no ill will toward him since we learned of the circumstances of the collision." The driver, Ray Czechowski served 6 months and was disqualified from driving for 3 years.{{cite web |last=Bueche |first=Will |title=Driver In Dr John Mack Accident Sentenced |url=http://ufoupdateslist.com/2005/oct/m08-012.shtml |work=UFO Updates |date= October 7, 2005 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} ==Works== He wrote the following books: * ''Passport to the Cosmos: Human Transformation and Alien Encounters'' (1999) * ''Abduction: Human Encounters with Aliens'' (1994) * ''A Prince of Our Disorder: The Life of T.E. Lawrence'' (1976) * ''Nightmares and Human Conflict'' (1970) Collaborations: * ''The Alchemy of Survival: One Woman's Journey'' (1988) * ''Vivienne: The Life and Suicide of an Adolescent School Girl'' (1977) He was editor or co-editor of: * ''Mind Before Matter: Vision of a New Science of Consciousness'' (2007; succeeded by [[Paul Devereux]]) * ''Alien Discussions: Proceedings of the Abduction Study Conference Held at M.I.T. Cambridge, MA'' (1995) * ''Human Feelings: Explorations in Affect Development and Meaning'' (1993) * ''Development and Sustenance of Self-Esteem in Childhood'' (1984) * ''Borderline States in Psychiatry - Seminars in Psychiatry'' (1975) Unpublished: * ''When Worldviews Collide: A Paradigmatic Passion Play'', a manuscript about the Harvard inquiry, was largely complete at the time of his death and is in-development as a motion picture.{{cite web |title=The John Mack Project: A True Story |url=http://makemagicproductions.com/johnmack/ |work=MakeMagic Productions |year=2011 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} * ''Elisabeth and Mark Before and After Death: The Power of a Field of Love'',{{cite web |last=Blumenthal|first=Ralph |title=Alien Nation |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2013/05/americans-alien-abduction-science |work=Vanity Fair |date= May 9, 2013 |access-date=May 10, 2013}} described in Vanity Fair as an unpublished manuscript about [[Elisabeth Targ|Dr. Elisabeth Targ]], in fact exists only as an outline and as hours of interview transcripts. He also wrote the foreword to ''Paths Beyond Ego: The Transpersonal Vision'' (1993), the introductions to ''The PK Man: A True Story of Mind Over Matter'' (2000) by [[Jeffrey Mishlove]] and ''Secret Life'' (1992) by [[David M. Jacobs]], and he contributed chapters to several books including ''The Long Darkness: Psychological and Moral Perspectives on Nuclear Winter'' (1986), ''The Psychology of Terrorism Vol. 1: A Public Understanding'' (2002), and ''The Psychospiritual Clinician's Handbook'' (2005). ==Popular culture== * He was illustrated by cartoonist [[Roz Chast]] in a four-page color strip, ''Aliens, Ahoy!'', published in [[Duke University]]'s DoubleTake magazine, Winter 1999 issue.{{cite web |title=Dr John Mack in the Arts |url=http://johnemackinstitute.org/1999/12/dr-john-mack-in-the-arts/ |work=John E. Mack Institute |year=2011 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} * He appears as a character in [[William Baer (writer)|William Baer]]'s book of poetry, ''The Unfortunates'' (1997). * He was interviewed for the documentary film about the Dalai Lama, ''[[Dalai Lama Renaissance]]'',{{cite web |title=Dalai Lama Renaissance: documentary film |url=http://www.dalailamafilm.com |work=Dalai Lama Renaissance |publisher=Wakan Films and Khashyar Darvich |year=2011 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} where he spoke about his conversations with the Dalai Lama about aliens,{{cite web |title=Dalai Lama Renaissance: John E. Mack - Biography |url=http://dalailamafilm.com/cast-john-e-mack/john-e-mack-biography-ufo-ufos-aliens-alien-abduction.html |work=Dalai Lama Renaissance |publisher=Wakan Films and Khashyar Darvich |year=2011 |access-date=September 27, 2011}} but the interview was not included in the final edit of the film. * The rights to Mack's life story were secured in 2012 by MakeMagic Productions for feature film development.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |author=Mack, John E. |title=Nightmares and Human Conflict |location=Boston | publisher=Little, Brown |year=1970 |isbn=0-7000-0188-3}} * {{cite book |author=Mack, John E. |title=Borderline States In Psychiatry |location=New York |publisher=Grune & Stratton |year=1975 |isbn=0-8089-0878-2}} * {{cite book |author=Mack, John E. |title=A Prince of Our Disorder: the life of T. E. Lawrence |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown |year=1976 |isbn=0-316-54232-6}} * {{cite book |author=Matheson, Terry |title=Alien Abduction: Creating A Modern Phenomenon |location= |publisher=Prometheus Books |year=1998 |isbn= 1-57392-244-7}} {{refend}} == External links == {{Wikiquote}} {{refbegin}} * [http://www.johnemackinstitute.org The John E. 1982 ''[[Aces Go Places]]'' }} '''Karl Maka''' ({{Lang-zh|t=麥嘉}}) is a [[Hong Kong people|Hong Kong]] film producer, director, actor and presenter. He was born on 29 February 1944 in [[Taishan, Guangdong|Taishan]], China. {{Eastern Slavic name|Isayevich|Aushev}} {{Infobox football biography | image = | name = Khavazh Aushev | fullname = Khavazh Isayevich Aushev | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|07|9|df=yes}} | height = {{height|m=1.80}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]]/[[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[FC Angusht Nazran]] | clubnumber = | years1 = 2014–2016 | clubs1 = [[FC Angusht Nazran]] | caps1 = 31 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2016–2018 | clubs2 = [[FC Amkar Perm]] | caps2 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = [[FC Angusht Nazran]] | caps3 = | goals3 = | pcupdate = 20 May 2018 | ntupdate = }} '''Khavazh Isayevich Aushev''' ({{lang-ru|Хаваж Исаевич Аушев}}; born 9 July 1997) is a [[Russia]]n [[association football|football]] player. He plays for [[FC Angusht Nazran]].
==Club career== He made his professional debut in the [[Russian Professional Football League]] for [[FC Angusht Nazran]] on 18 November 2014 in a game against [[FC Astrakhan]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[Russian Football Union]]|url=http://www.pfl-russia.com/competitions/season-2014-2015/south/player.php?player=20286|title=Career Summary|date=11 March 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== He is the younger brother of [[Apti Aushev]].

{{Infobox person | name = | image = Lacey Chabert.jpg | caption = Lacey Chabert in 2007 | birth_name = Lacey Nicole Chabert | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1982|09|30}} | height = 5 ft 3 in (1.60 m) | birth_place = [[ Purvis, Mississippi]], U.S. | occupation = {{flatlist| *Actress *voice actress *singer }} | years_active = 1990–present | spouse = {{marriage|David Nehdar|2013}} | children = Julia Mimi Bella Nehdar | website = www.laceychabert.com }} '''Lacey Nicole Chabert''' ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|ə|ˈ|b|ɛ|r}}; born September 30, 1982) is an American [[actress]], [[voice actress]], and [[singer]]. Chabert landed one of her first roles playing Erica Kane's daughter on ''[[All My Children]]''. She was the third actress to play Bianca Montgomery from 1992 until 1993. Then gained prominence as a [[Child actor|child actress]] on television for her first big role as [[Claudia Salinger]] in the television drama ''[[Party of Five]]'' (1994–2000).<ref>{{cite news|title= The 'sparkle' that holds Fox's 'Party of Five' together is called Lacey|work= The Los Angeles Times|date=1994-10-23|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-10-23/news/tv-53562_1_lacey-chabert|accessdate=2010-09-24|first=N.F.|last=Mendoza}}</ref> She has also provided the voice of Eliza Thornberry in the animated series ''[[The Wild Thornberrys]]'' (1998–2004) and two feature films, [[Meg Griffin]] during the first production season of the animated sitcom ''[[Family Guy]]'',<ref name=Epstein>{{cite web|title=Interview with Seth MacFarlane, creator of The Family Guy |publisher=UGO.com |author=Daniel Robert Epstein |url=http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmTv/features/familyguy/sethmacfarlane.asp |accessdate=2009-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218041854/http://www.ugo.com/channels/filmTv/features/familyguy/sethmacfarlane.asp |archivedate=December 18, 2008 }}</ref> and superheroine [[Zatanna|Zatanna Zatara]] in various pieces of [[DC Comics]]-related media. In film, she has appeared in ''[[Lost in Space (film)|Lost in Space]]'' (1998), ''[[Not Another Teen Movie]]'' (2001), and ''[[Daddy Day Care]]'' (2003), and had leading roles as Gretchen Wieners in ''[[Mean Girls]]'' (2004), Meg Cummings in ''[[Dirty Deeds (2005 film)|Dirty Deeds]]'' (2005), and Dana Mathis in the horror remake ''[[Black Christmas (2006 film)|Black Christmas]]'' (2006).
Chabert has also appeared in 17 [[Hallmark Channel]] movies,<ref>http://www.hallmarkchannel.com/search?first=RELEVANT&second=MOVIE&q=Lacey+Chabert</ref> saying "I love working for Hallmark. They've been so good to me. I have friends there now. I'm proud of their movies and the message of their movies."<ref name="Hollywood Daily Star">{{cite web | title=Hallmark A Family For Christmas, Lacey Chabert Wakes Up as a Wife with Two Kids| publisher=HollywoodDailyStar.com| first=Gabrielle| last=Pantera | url=http://www.hollywooddailystar.com/?p=4041| accessdate=2015-07-10 }}</ref>
== Early life == Chabert was born in [[Purvis, Mississippi]], to Julie (née Johnson) and Tony Chabert. Her father is of [[Cajun]], Italian, and English descent; he worked as a maintenance operations representative for an oil company.<ref name="chabert1">{{cite web | title=Vibe chat| publisher=Lacey Chabert.com| year=1998 | url=http://lacey-chabert.dayah.com/text/VIBE.html| accessdate=2006-11-24 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/36/Lacey-Chabert.html |title=Lacey Chabert Biography (1982–) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-03}}</ref> Her mother has English, Scottish, and remote Italian ancestry.<ref name="imdb">{{IMDb name|327|Lacey Chabert}}</ref> Chabert has a younger brother named T.J., and two older sisters, Chrissy and Wendy. She was "World's Baby Petite" in the "World's Our Little Miss Scholarship Competition" in 1985.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ourlittlemiss.com/Where_Are_They_Now_.html |title=Where Are They Now? |publisher=Ourlittlemiss.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127102426/http://www.ourlittlemiss.com/Where_Are_They_Now_.html |archivedate=2010-01-27 |df= }}</ref> In 1992 and 1993, she played young [[Cosette]] in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]''.
== Career == Chabert played the role of Cosette in ''Les Misérables'' on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] before taking the role of Claudia Salinger in ''[[Party of Five]]''. Chabert made her big screen debut in the late 1990s, starring as Penny Robinson in the space thriller ''[[Lost in Space (film)|Lost in Space]]'' (1998). Since then, she has been the voice of [[Eliza Thornberry]] in the [[animated series]] ''[[The Wild Thornberrys]]'', and has voiced Eliza in two films, ''[[The Wild Thornberrys Movie]]'' (2002) and ''[[Rugrats Go Wild]]'' (2003). She then had a [[supporting role]] in the [[parody]] film ''[[Not Another Teen Movie]]'' as Amanda Becker. She provided the voice for the [[title character]]'s daughter Aleu in ''[[Balto 2: Wolf Quest]]'' (2002) and she provided the voice of [[Meg Griffin]] for the first production season of the [[animated sitcom]] ''[[Family Guy]]'' (1999), after which [[Mila Kunis]] took over the role.<ref name=Epstein/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://info.sonicretro.org/Lacey_Chabert_interview_by_GameSpy_%28October_6,_2006%29|title=Lacey Chabert interview by GameSpy (October 6, 2006)|work=Sonic Retro}}</ref>
Chabert played the [[title role]] in ''[[Brooke Ellison#The Brooke Ellison Story|The Brooke Ellison Story]]'', a movie [[Film producer|produced]] and [[Film director|directed]] by [[Christopher Reeve]], based upon a real-life [[quadriplegic]] woman who overcame many obstacles to graduate from [[Harvard University]]. She starred in ''[[Mean Girls]]'' (2004) and the [[television film]] ''[[Hello Sister, Goodbye Life]]'' (2006) on [[ABC Family]]. She appeared in a [[Black Christmas (2006 film)|2006 remake]] of ''[[Black Christmas (1974 film)|Black Christmas]]''. She appeared in an [[episode]] of ''[[Ghost Whisperer]]'' opposite former ''Party of Five'' costar [[Jennifer Love Hewitt]]. She performed the voice of [[Princess Elise]] from the game ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (2006 video game)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'' for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]]. She also voiced [[Gwen Stacy]] in the [[animated series]] ''[[The Spectacular Spider-Man (TV series)|The Spectacular Spider-Man]]''.
Chabert, along with [[Lindsay Lohan]], [[Rachel McAdams]], and [[Amanda Seyfried]], won the 2005 [[MTV Movie Awards 2005|MTV Movie Award]] for Best On-Screen Team for ''Mean Girls''. She won both the 1997 and 1998 ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' Annual YoungStar Award for Best Performance by a Young Actress in a Drama TV Series for ''Party of Five'', and had been [[nominated]] three other times for work from 1999 to 2000.<ref name="imdb"/> The YoungStar awards honor the best film, TV, and music performances made exclusively by six- to 18-year-olds.
In 2007, Chabert starred in the [[pilot episode]] of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] comedy "The Hot Years", which revolved around the lives of four female friends who live together. The pilot was not ordered to series by Fox.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/devwatch/hot-years/|title=Shows A-Z - hot years, the on fox - TheFutonCritic.com|work=thefutoncritic.com}}</ref>
Chabert was featured as [[cover girl]] of the January 2007 issue of ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'',<ref name="maxim">{{cite news|first=Maria|last=Fontoura|title=Jessica Hundley|date=January 2007|publisher=Maxim Magazine Online|url=http://www.maximonline.com/articles/index.aspx?a_id=7381|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070120181603/http://www.maximonline.com/articles/index.aspx?a_id=7381|archivedate=2007-01-20|accessdate=2007-01-23}}</ref> and again in November 2013.
From 2013–2014, Chabert had a [[recurring role]] on the ABC Family sitcom ''[[Baby Daddy]]'' as Dr. Amy Shaw.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Steven Hack |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/12/19/abc-family-casts-lacey-chabert-and-grace-phipps-to-guest-star-in-new-episodes-of-original-series-baby-daddy/162488/ |title=ABC Family Casts Lacey Chabert and Grace Phipps to Guest Star in New Episodes of Original Series 'Baby Daddy' - Ratings | TVbytheNumbers |publisher=Tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com |date= |accessdate=December 20, 2012}}</ref> After working in various TV movies during this time, she opened 2018 with an original Hallmark movie that premiered as part of the Valentine's Day Countdown.
== Personal life == Chabert married her longtime boyfriend, David Nehdar, on December 22, 2013, in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite news|last=Blumm|first=K.C.|title=Lacey Chabert Is Married|work=People|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20772015,00.html|date=January 3, 2014|accessdate=January 4, 2014}}</ref> Chabert gave birth to their daughter, Julia Mimi Bella Nehdar on September 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Juneau|first1=Jen|title=Lacey Chabert Welcomes Daughter Julia Mimi Bella|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2016/09/08/lacey-chabert-welcomes-daughter-julia-mimi-bella/|accessdate=September 8, 2016|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=September 8, 2016}}</ref>
Chabert has spoken publicly about her faith and said she related to her character in ''[[Christian Mingle]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faith.com/video/Lacey-Chabert-Opens-Up-About-Her-Faith-Finding-The-One/|title=http://www.faith.com/video/Lacey-Chabert-Opens-Up-About-Her-Faith-Finding-The-One/|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* Middle Ages: 400–1585 */
revision.text:
{{For|software and media pirates|List of warez groups}} {{see also|list of fictional pirates|List of pirate films}} {{More footnotes|date=September 2008}} This is a list of known pirates, [[buccaneer]]s, [[Privateer|corsairs]], [[privateer]]s, [[piracy|river pirates]], and others involved in [[piracy]] and piracy-related activities. This list includes both captains and prominent crew members. For a list of female pirates, see [[women in piracy]]. For pirates of fiction or myth, see [[list of fictional pirates]]. ==Ancient World: 315 BC–197 AD== [[Image:Pompey by Nasidius.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Denarius]] coin of [[Sextus Pompeius]], Roman pirate and general from the [[Roman Republic]] era of 44–43 BC. AR Denarius (3.85 g, 3h). Massilia (Gaul) mint. Q. Nasidius, moneyer. Bare head of Pompey the Great right; trident before, dolphin below / Ship sailing right; star above.]] [[File:GanNing.jpg|150px|thumb|right|[[Gan Ning]] was a notorious pirate and marauder in the late 190s CE, who became a Chinese military general serving under the warlord [[Sun Quan]] in the late [[Eastern Han dynasty]].]] {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! style="width:21%;" | Name ! style="width: 7%;" data-sort-type="number" | Life ! style="width: 7%;" data-sort-type="number" | Years active ! style="width:10%;" | Country of origin ! style="width:55%;" | Comments |- | '''{{sortname||Anicetus|Anicetus (Pontus)}}''' | {{sort|069|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 69}} | | [[Pontus (region)|Pontus]] ([[Ancient Greece|Hellenic]]) | Was the leader of an unsuccessful anti-Roman uprising in Pontus in 69 AD. |- | '''{{sortname||Demetrius of Pharos}}''' | {{sort|-214|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 214 BC}} | | [[Hvar|Pharos]] ([[Ancient Greece|Hellenic]]) | His actions precipitated the [[Illyrian Wars|Second Illyrian War]]. |- | '''{{sortname||Dionysius the Phocaean}}''' | {{sort|-494|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 494 BC}} | {{sort|-494|494 BC}} | [[Greece]] | [[Phocaean]] admiral active against [[Ancient Carthage|Carthaginian]] and [[Tyrsenians|Tyrsenian]] merchants in the years following the [[Greco–Persian Wars]]. |- | '''{{sortname||Gan Ning}}''' | {{sort|180–210|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 180s–210s}} | 190–197 | [[China]] | His party carried bells as their trademark to frighten the commoners. |- | '''{{sortname||Genthus of Illyria}}''' | {{sort|-181-168|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 181–168 BC}} | | [[Illyria]] | Was accused by the Romans of organizing and aiding pirate raids in Italy. |- | '''{{sortname||Glauketas}}''' | {{sort|-315-300|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 315–300 BC}} | {{sort|-315-300|315–300 BC}} | | Greek inscriptions of the Athenian navy raiding his base on Kynthnos Island and capturing him and his men, "making the sea safe for those that sailed thereon." |- | '''{{sortname|Sextus|Pompeius}}''' | {{sort|-067-035|67–35 BC}} | | [[Rome]] | He was the last focus of opposition to the [[Second Triumvirate]]. |} ==Middle Ages: 400–1585== [[File:Arudsch-barbarossa.jpg|150px|thumb|right|[[Oruç Reis|Aruj, or Oruç, Reis]] was a Barbary privateer and later Admiral in Ottoman service who became known as Barbarossa – or Redbeard – amongst Christians.]] [[File:Awilda.jpg|150px|thumb|right|[[Awilda]] was a 5th-century pirate who, along with friends, dressed up as sailors and commandeered a ship.]] [[Image:Rekonstruierter Schaedel.jpg|145px|right|thumb|[[Klaus Störtebeker]] was a 14th-15th century German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former [[Victual Brothers]] (Vitalienbrüder) who roamed [[Northern Europe]]an seas.]] [[File:Yermak Timofeyevich.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Yermak Timofeyevich, a 16th-century [[Cossack]] river pirate who started the [[Russia]]n [[conquest of Siberia]] in the reign of Tsar [[Ivan the Terrible]]]] {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! style="width:21%;" | Name ! style="width: 7%;" | Life ! style="width: 7%;" | Years Active ! style="width:10%;" | Country of origin ! style="width:55%;" | Comments |- | '''{{sortname|Giorgio|Adorno||nolink=1}}''' | {{sort|1558|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1558}} | | [[Malta]] | [[Knights Hospitaller|Knight of Malta]] active in the Mediterranean. Originally from [[Naples]], he was elected "Captain-General of the Galleys" in 1547, 1549, 1557 and 1558.Rogozinski, Jan. ''Pirates!: Brigands, Buccaneers, and Privateers in Fact, Fiction, and Legend''. New York: Da Capo Press, 1996. {{ISBN|0-306-80722-X}} |- | '''{{sortname|James|Alday|}}''' | 1516–1576 | 1540s | [[England]] | An English privateer. Raided Spanish ports with James Logan and William Cooke. |- | '''{{sortname|William|Aleyn}}''' | {{sort|1448|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 1448}} | 1432–1448 | [[England]] | English pirate active in the [[Thames]] and [[English Channel]]. Associate of [[William Kyd]]. |- | '''{{sortname|Jean|Ango}}''' | 1480–1551 | | [[France]] | A French ship-owner who provided ships to [[Francis I of France|Francis I]] for exploration of the globe. |- | '''{{sortname||Aruj}}''' | 1474–1518 | 1503–1518 | [[Ottoman Empire]] | An [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] privateer and Bey (Governor) of Algiers and Beylerbey (Chief Governor) of the West Mediterranean. |- | '''{{sortname||Awilda}}''' | {{sort|0400|5th century}} | | [[Scandinavia]] | She and some of her female friends dressed like sailors and commandeered a ship. |- | '''{{sortname|Hayreddin|Barbarossa}}''' | {{sort|1478-1546|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1478–1546}} | 1504–1545 | [[Ottoman Empire]] | An Ottoman privateer and later Admiral who dominated the Mediterranean for decades. |- | '''{{sortname||Barnim VI, Duke of Pomerania||Barnim 6}}''' | {{sort|1365-1405|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1365–1405}} | 1394–1405 | [[Germany]] ([[Duchy of Pomerania|Pomerania]]) | A Pomeranian duke supporting privateers in the Baltic Sea region and later going on pirate raids himself. |- | '''{{sortname|Baldassare|Cossa|Antipope John XXIII}}''' | 1370–1415 | | [[Procida]] | [[Antipope]] during the [[Western Schism]], John XXIII was accused of—among other crimes—[[piracy]], [[incest]] and [[sodomy]]. |- | '''{{sortname|John|Crabbe|John Crabbe (died 1352)}}''' | {{sort|1352|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1352}} | 1305–1332 | [[Flanders]] | Flemish pirate best known for his successful use of a ship-mounted catapult. Once won the favor of Robert the Bruce and acted as a naval officer for England during the Hundred Years' War (after being captured by King Edward III.) |- | '''{{sortname|Pier Gerlofs|Donia}}''' | {{sort|1480-1520|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1480–1520}} | | [[Netherlands]] ([[Frisia]]) | a Frisian [[warrior]], [[pirate]], [[freedom fighter]], [[folk hero]] and [[Rebellion|rebel]]. |- | '''{{sortname|Erlend|Eindridesson||nolink=1}}''' | | 1445–? | [[Norway]] | [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[nobleman]], plundered [[Germany|German]] ships in the [[Sognefjord]]. |- | '''{{sortname||Eric of Pomerania}}''' | {{sort|1381-1459|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1381-82–1459}} | | [[Germany]] ([[Duchy of Pomerania|Pomerania]]) | The first king of the Nordic [[Kalmar Union]], he spent his last years living on the island of [[Gothland]] and ''"sent forth piratical expeditions against friend and foe alike"''.''Library of Universal Knowledge: A Reprint of the Last (1880) Edinburgh and London Edition of Chambers's Encyclopedia''. New York: American Book Exchange, 1880. (pg. 510) |- | '''{{sortname|Alv|Erlingsson}}''' | {{sort|1290|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1290}} | | [[Norway]] | He was a favorite of the Queen, yet committed countless acts of piracy throughout his life |- | '''{{sortname||Eustace the Monk}}''' | {{sort|1170-1217|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1170–1217}} | | [[France]] | He was a mercenary for both England and France. |- | '''{{sortname|Jean|Fleury}}''' | {{sort|1527|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1523}} | {{sort|1521-1527|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1521-1527}} | [[France]] | French privateer and naval officer under [[Jean Ango]]. Seized three Spanish ships carrying [[Aztec]] treasure from Mexico to Spain in 1523. |- | '''{{sortname|Magnus|Heinason}}''' | 1545–1589 | | [[Faroe Islands]] | [[Faroese people|Faroese]] naval hero and privateer. Was executed for piracy, though charges were later dropped. |- | '''{{sortname|Klein|Henszlein}}''' | {{sort|1573|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1573}} | 1560–1573 | [[Germany]] | A 16th-century pirate who raided shipping in the North Sea until his defeat and capture by a fleet from Hamburg |- | '''{{sortname|Wijerd|Jelckama}}''' | {{sort|1490-1523|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1490–1523}} | | [[Germany]] ([[Frisia]]) | The nephew of Pier Gerlofs Donia (also known as Grutte Pier), fought along his side against the [[Lower Saxony|Saxon]] and [[Hollandic]] invaders. |- | '''{{sortname|William|Kyd}}''' | {{sort|1430-1453|''{{abbr|fl.|Floruit}}'' 1430–1453}} | {{sort|1430-1450|1430s–1450s}} | [[England]] | English pirate active in [[Southwest England]] during the early-to-mid-15th century. |- | '''{{sortname|Gödeke|Michels}}''' | {{sort|1402|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1402}} | 1392–1402 | [[Germany]] | A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former [[Victual Brothers]] (Vitalienbrüder) |- | '''{{sortname|Martin|Pechlin||nolink=1}}''' | 1480–1526 | | [[Germany]] | Died in [[Mandal, Norway|Mandal]], [[Norway]]. One of the most feard [[Piracy|pirates]] in his time |- | '''{{sortname|Didrik|Pining}}''' | {{sort|1430-1491|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1430–1491}} | | [[Denmark-Norway]] | A pirate and privateer operating in the [[North Sea]]. Often partnered with [[Hans Pothorst]]. |- | '''{{sortname|Hans|Pothorst}}''' | {{sort|1440-1490|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1440–1490}} | | [[Denmark-Norway]] | A pirate and privateer operating in the [[North Sea]]. Often partnered with [[Didrik Pining]]. |- | '''{{sortname|Salih|Reis}}''' | {{sort|1488-1568|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1488–1568}} | | [[Ottoman Empire]] | A Turkish privateer and Ottoman admiral. |- | '''{{sortname|Turgut|Reis}}''' | 1485–1565 | | [[Ottoman Empire]] | A Turkish privateer and Ottoman admiral as well as Bey of Algiers; Beylerbey of the Mediterranean; and first Bey later Pasha of Tripoli. |- | '''{{sortname|Klaus|Störtebeker}}''' | 1360–1401 | 1392–1401 | [[Germany]] | A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former [[Victual Brothers]] (Vitalienbrüder) |- | '''{{sortname|Yermak|Timofeyevich}}''' | {{sort|1532-1585|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1532-42–1585}} | {{sort|1581|?–1582}} | [[Russia]] | A leader of a gang of river pirates, along the [[Don River (Russia)|Don River]] region, of Russia and later, led an expedition, in the Russian conquest of Siberia, in the reign of Tsar Ivan the Terrible. |- | '''{{sortname|Kristoffer|Trondson}}''' | {{sort|1500-1565|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1500–1565}} | {{sort|1535-1542|''{{abbr|c.|Circa}}'' 1535–1542}} | [[Norway]] | A Norwegian nobleman-turned pirate and privateer. Operated in the [[North Sea]] and the [[Baltic Sea]]. Gave up piracy in 1542 and eventually, became admiral of the Danish Fleet. |- | '''{{sortname|Bartholomeus|Voet||nolink=1}}'''{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/254874614|title=Pirater og sjørøvere i norske farvann|last=Ingebrigt|first=Hetland,|date=2008|publisher=Pantagruel|isbn=9788279003236|location=Oslo|oclc=254874614}} | {{sort|1400|''{{abbr|b.|Born}}'' early 1400}} | | [[Norway]] | Second leader of [[Victual Brothers|Victual Brohers]], plundered and burned down the [[Norway|norweagian]] city [[Sacking of Bergen (1393)|Bergen in 1429]] |- | '''{{sortname|Hennig|Wichmann}}''' | 1370–1402 | 1392–1402 | [[Germany]] | A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former [[Victual Brothers]] (Vitalienbrüder) |- | '''{{sortname|Cord|Widderich}}''' | {{sort|1447|''{{abbr|d.|Death}}'' 1447}} | 1404–1447 | [[Germany]] | A pirate active during political conflicts between [[Dithmarschen]] and [[North Frisia]] in the early 15th century. |- | '''{{sortname|Magister|Wigbold}}''' | 1365–1402 | 1392–1402 | [[Germany]] | A German pirate and one of the leaders of the Likedeelers, a combination of former [[Victual Brothers]] (Vitalienbrüder) |- | '''{{sortname||Wimund}}''' | {{sort|1147|''{{abbr|b.|Born}}'' 1147}} | | [[England]] | He was a bishop who became a seafaring warlord adventurer. |} ==Rise of the English Sea Dogs and Dutch Corsairs: 1560–1650== [[File:Thomas Cavendish.jpg|150px|thumb|right|The first man to intentionally circumnavigate the globe, [[Thomas Cavendish]] also raided numerous Spanish towns and ships in the New World.]] [[File:1590 or later Marcus Gheeraerts, Sir Francis Drake Buckland Abbey, Devon.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Known as "el Draque" (the Dragon), Sir [[Francis Drake]] was considered a hero in England, but little more than a pirate in Spain.]] [[File:Piet Hein.jpg|150px|thumb|right|After serving as a Spanish galley slave for four years, [[Piet Pieterszoon Hein|Piet Hein]] later captured 11,509,524 guilders of cargo from the Spanish treasure fleet.]] [[File:The meeting of Grace O'Malley and Queen Elizabeth I.jpg|150px|thumb|right|[[Gráinne O'Malley]] (left of frame) was an important figure in Irish legend who is still recognised in popular culture today.]] [[File:John Hawkins.JPG|thumb|150px|right|Sir [[John Hawkins (naval commander)|John Hawkins]]. An Elizabethan corsair and some-time slaves trader in West Africa and Venezuelan coasts. ]] [[File:Sir Francis Verney.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Sir [[Francis Verney]] was one of the most feared [[Barbary corsairs]] during the early 17th century.]] [[File:Jameslancaster.jpg|150px|thumb|Sir James Lancaster VI commanded the first East India Company voyage in 1601]] [[File:William Segar Sir Walter Raleigh 1598.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Sir Walter Raleigh who commanded two expedition to search the golden city of [[El Dorado]] in Spanish colony of Guayana (actual Venezuela)]] [[File:Sir George Somers portrait.jpg|thumb|150px|Sir [[George Somers]]. He later became a buccaneer. |} ==[[Golden Age of Piracy]]: 1690–1730== [[File:Bartholomew Roberts.jpg|150px|thumb|right|The most successful pirate of the Golden Age of Piracy, [[Bartholomew Roberts|Black Bart]] was estimated to have captured more than 470 vessels.]] [[File:Blackbeard.gif|150px|thumb|right|With his fearsome appearance, [[Blackbeard]] is often credited with the creation of the stereotypical image of a pirate.]] [[File:Miguel Enriquez.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Miguel Enríquez was the most longeve and the wealthiest of the privateers born in the Caribbean colonies.{{cite web|url=http://www.vozdelcentro.org/2007/04/01/miguel-enriquez-el-primer-gran-heroe-nacional/|title=Miguel Enríquez: el primer gran héroe nacional|author=Ángel Collado Schwarz|publisher=La Voz del Centro|language=Spanish|date=2007-03-01|accessdate=2016-07-08}}]] [[File:Amaro Pargo.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Amaro Pargo]]. He was one of the most famous pirates of the [[golden age of piracy]], and one of the most important personalities of the [[18th century]] of Spain.]] [[File:Female pirate Anne Bonny.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Despite never commanding a ship herself, [[Anne Bonny]] is remembered as one of few female historical pirates.]] [[File:Every,Henry.JPG|150px|thumb|right|[[Henry Every]] (or Avery) is famous as one of the few pirates of the era who was able to retire with his takings without being either arrested or killed in battle.]] [[File:William Kidd.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Although modern historians dispute the legitimacy of his trial and execution, the rumour of [[William Kidd|Captain Kidd]]'s buried treasure has served only to build a legend around the man as a great pirate.]] {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! style="width:21%;"| Name ! style="width:7%;"| Life ! style="width:7%;"| Years Active ! style="width:10%;"| Country of origin ! style="width:55%;"| Comments |- |'''[[James Allison (pirate)|James Allison]]''' |? |1689-1691 |Colonial America |Active near [[Cape Verde]] and the [[Bay of Campeche]]. He is best known for capturing pirates [[Calico Jack]], [[Anne Bonney]], and [[Mary Read]]. |- |'''[[Thomas Barrow (pirate)|Thomas Barrow]]''' |d. 1726 |1702–1718 |Unknown |Pirate active in the [[Caribbean]]. He is best known for proclaiming himself Governor of [[New Providence]]. |- |'''[[Don Benito (pirate)|Don Benito]]''' |? |1725 |Spain |Real name possibly '''Benito Socarras Y Aguero''', he was a Spanish pirate and ''guarda costa'' [[privateer]] active in the [[Caribbean]]. |- |'''[[Charles Bellamy]]''' |? |1717–1720 |England |English pirate who raided colonial American shipping in New England and later off the coast of Canada. He is often confused with the more well-known [[Samuel Bellamy|Samuel "Black Sam" Bellamy]], as they operated in the same areas at the same time. |- valign="top" | '''[[Samuel Bellamy|Samuel Bellamy (Black Sam)]]''' | 1689–1717 | 1716–1717 | Hittisleigh, Devonshire, England | Despite having a career of only 16 months, Bellamy was extraordinarily successful, capturing more than 50 ships before his death at age 28. His acquired wealth of five tons of treasure from his short career is speculated at US $120 million in 2008 dollars.{{Cite news |last=Woolsey |first=Matt |date=19 September 2008 |title=Top-Earning Pirates |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/09/18/top-earning-pirates-biz-logistics-cx_mw_0919piracy.html |accessdate=8 October 2012 |newspaper=Forbes Magazine}} Bellamy began his pirate career under the command of Henry Jennings, a Buccaneer that turned pirate; but double-crossing Jennings, Bellamy fled to the Bahamas and joined Jennings' nemesis, Benjamin Hornigold of the ''Mary Anne''. But quickly growing wearisome of Hornigold's refusal to attack English ships, Bellamy called for a vote of no confidence, and the crew ousted Hornigold and Blackbeard by a majority vote, electing Bellamy as captain. Bellamy's prize flagship, ''[[Whydah Galley]]'', discovered by underwater explorer [[Barry Clifford]] in 1984, is currently the world's only fully authenticated Golden Age pirate shipwreck ever found. |- valign="top" | '''[[Blackbeard|Blackbeard (Edward Teach)]]''' | 1680–1718 | 1716–1718 | England | With his fearsome appearance, Blackbeard is often credited with the creation of the stereotypical image of a pirate. Although his real name remains unknown, he began his pirate career as the first officer of Buccaneer-turned-pirate Captain Benjamin Hornigold of the ''Mary Anne''. When a young crewman, Samuel Bellamy, called for a vote of no confidence in Hornigold for his refusal to attack English ships, the crew by a vote ousted Hornigold and Blackbeard, leaving the ''Mary Anne'' to Bellamy whom the crew elected their new captain. His legend solidified after he took command of the ''[[Queen Anne's Revenge]]''.D. Moore. (1997) "A General History of Blackbeard the Pirate, the Queen Anne's Revenge and the Adventure". In Tributaries, Volume VII, 1997. pp. 31–35. (North Carolina Maritime History Council) |- valign="top" | '''[[Black Caesar (pirate)|Black Caesar]]''' | d. 1718 | 1700s–1718 | Africa | A captured slave turned pirate, Black Caesar was a well-known pirate active off the [[Florida Keys]] during the early 18th century. He later acted as a lieutenant to [[Blackbeard]] and was one of five Africans serving on his flagship. |- |'''[[Augustin Blanco]]''' |? |1700-1725 |Cuba |He was noted for attacking in open boats, and for having a mixed-race crew. |- |'''[[Richard Bobbington]]''' |d. 1697 |1695–1696 |Unknown |Active in the [[Red Sea]], [[Indian Ocean]], and [[Persian Gulf]]. Sailed with [[Thomas Tew]]'s crew after Tew's death.
